euen high treason insomuch seneca writeth certaine senator fearing bee bewraied slaue craued pardon tiberius bene touch chamber pot ring vpon finger wherein image tiberius engrauen sort image time spaniard subdued thing could possibly extreame violent forcing free lawes nature yet past seuentie yeares people gaoga africke neuer felt heard king lord whatsoeuer vntill one amongst trauell trauell seene noted maiestie king tombut thereupon conceiuing desire make himselfe king also owne countrie hee first begin withall killed rich marchant possessed horse armes marchandise diuided amongst nie kinsfolk friend acquainted purpose whose aid force violence subdued others killing richest ceasing vpon good sort sonne became rich robbery father made himselfe king whose successor hath continued great power read leo africke beginning king gaoga short time greatly encreased thus much concerning beginning commonweal may serue manifest definition citisen v set true thing say free subiect holding soueraignitie another man free subiect citisen must free subiect say albeit slaue much subiect vnto commaund highest authoritie free man yet al people haue alwayes common consent agreed slaue citisen question right accounted noslaues bee accounted citisens bodie cannot truely said men wiues child free seruitude bondage albeit right liberty power dispose owne good sort cut domesticall power sort man may say euerie citisen subiect small part libertie diminished maiestie whome oweth obeysance euerie subiect citisen haue said slaue may also say stranger comming man segniorie receiued citisen hauing part right priueledges citie neither bee accounted number friend ally coallies altogether straungers lawyer saith neither enemy also howbeit greek old called straungers enemy also latines cicero hath noted law twelue table cice officiorum lib 1 mildnesse word saith mitigating hardnesse thing called enemy conspired state may well bee also yet common word cal hotes hostes antient time nothing el straungers men haue since corrected proprietie word forme speech still remaining greek haue called enemy 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 men making warre vpon straungers haue lost except law made recouerie thing lost againe recouered thus much hee first writeth concerning athenian law solon long abolished admitted straunger freedome citisen athens except banished owne countrey law plutarch wondreth aboue measure foreseeing haue bene done solon end like man enioy immunitie priueleges citisen athens popular prerogatiue people except bound vnto commaund lawes athenian detained vnder commaund straunge citie hath without doubt lost right owne citie wise applied vnto king whome wee haue spoken yet rhodians ordained freedome athenian wherefore suppose tullius meant hee well agreeth himselfe indeed true citisen rome say bound vnto senat lawes people rome could bound vnto commaund another citie pomponius atticus borne citie rome roman citisen honourable order knight loue towards athenian thereof called atticus vnto whome three roman emperours referred beginning discent refused freedome citie athens offered athenian least saith cornelius nepos haue lost freedome citie rome true regard true subiects citisens citisens honour indeed subiects neither respect citisens diuers city vnder power one prince thing lawfull vnto euen roman law although one may slaue vassall many maisters lord yet man subiect diuers soueraigne prince mutuall consent prince vnder man commaund vnto whome seruice turne done slaues may magistrats enforced sell slaue except seruile labour cannot done turnes done slaue point oftentimes see warres betwixt neighbour prince subiects frontier well knowing whome obey submit themselues sometimes one sometimes oftentimes exempting themselues obeisance two ordinarily inuaded preyed vpon one countrey walachie hauing exempted self obeisance polonians hath become subiect vnto turk afterwards submitting selfe vnto king polonia paied tribute neuerthelesse vnto turke haue learned letter stanislaus rasdrazetoski sent c •… nstable france bearing date 17 august 1553 neuerthelesse many people vpon frontier haue set themselues libertie quarrel prince come passe low countrey leige lorraine burgundie twelue subiects french king empire spaine haue taken vpon soueraigntie amongst whome charles fist reckoned duke bouillon whome called vassall prisoner yeare 1556 treatie made deliuerance prisoner hee demaunded hundred thousand pound ransome called himselfe soueraigne prince well also others beside duke bouillon go marchesse burgundie called forbidden countrey six prince haue soueraigne power ouer subiects mutual war betwixt french burgundians haue long prescription time brought forth border lorraine county lume aspremont haue taken vpon right authoritie soueraigntie hath also happened vpon border england scotland particular men haue made themselues great commaunders within twenty thirty yeres antient agreement meet hominum dicitur qui cum romam venissent neque ciues romani essent participes tamen fuerunt omnium rerum ad munus fungendum vnà cum romani ciuibus praeterquam de suffragio ferendo aut magistratu capiendo sicut fuerunt fundani formiani cumani acerrani lanuuini tusculani qui post aliquot annos ciues romani effecti sunt al •… modo id genus hominum dicitur quorum ciuitas vniuersain ciuitatem bononienses placentini sutrini lucenses kind men saith hee called municipials comming rome citisens yet partaker thing together roman citisens except giuing voyces bearing office fundani formiani cumani acerrani lanuuini tusculani certaine yeares made citisens rome otherwise sort men called also whose whole citie came citie rome aricini cerites anagnini thirdly came vnto citie rome colony austria preiudice alliance made house austria presupposing empire superiour vnto swissers treaty alliance right superiour still excepted although thereof expresse mention made certaine much concerneth lawes maiestie swissers confesse emperor hath superioritie ouer much lesse emperour subiect state empire also true treatie made betwixt eight auntient canton expresse clause whereby canton zurich contrarie hereditarie alliance made betwixt prince house austria swissers yeare grace 1467 renewed yere 1501 league see rome pope empire excepted yerely pention set downe two hundred florin yeately paid vnto euery canton alliance againe renewed xiij canton diet bade holden xx day iuly 1554 league betwixt said lord canton french king onely league defensiue preseruation state ally inuading forreners true reason swissers withholden inuade territory empire house austria right preheminence superioritie empire hath ouer also yet expresly verified treatie alliance renewed betwixt french king lord canton iune 1549 excluded subiect swissers vse german tongue charles fift emperour laboured meanes make agreement swissers dukedome millan kingdom naples sicilie might comprised hereditarie accept euen german prince emperor appointed bishop 3 city grison variance among themselues choice bishop▪ swissers authority league taking vpon arbitrator controuersies arising betwixt confederat city conuentions agreement otherwise naturall bond say euery bond proper vnto ciuill law errour remoued doubt bond nature couenant wherefore couenant naturall common nation bond action arising thereof must need consequently nature also couenant almost neither obligation bond deuised common vnto law nature nation let v graunt couenants proceed meere ciuill law yet •… soue▪ raigne prince bound ciuil couenants dare deny prince straitly bound euen vnto ciuill couenants promise priuat subiects themselues yea strait maner cannot absolute power hath derogat almost learned lawyer opinion accord maruell seeing god bound vnto promise plainly protesteth prophet hieremie call together vnto saith people earth may iudge betwixt people thing ought haue done haue done let v noth therefore call question thing wherof many doctor haue doubted whether prince bound vnto couenants hath made subiects whereat need maruell seeing fountaine sprung lesse straunge position prince may right without iust cause record although still exercised country britaigne certaine roialties granted king great difference betwixt holdeth simply fealtie homage himselfe soueraigne subiect vnto lord fee soueraigne countrey yet vassall lord fee protection onely tributarie vnto prince hauing soueraigntie ouer subiects himselfe naturall subiect wherforethe prince holdeth another himselfe absolute soueraigne conclude none absolute soueraigne holdeth nothing another man considering vassall fee whatsoeuer hee pope emperor oweth personall seruice reason fee holdeth albeit word seruice matter fee customes preiudiciall vnto naturall libertie vassall yet importeth certaine right dutie honor reuerence vassall oweth vnto lord fee indeed seruitude reall annexed inseperable person vassall cannot therefrom freed quitting fee prouided yet hee bee naturall subiect lord fee whome cannot discharge himselfe renouncing fee say homage personall seruice inseperable vassallhomage personall seruice performed deputie true vassall cannot acquit himselfe thereof deputie atturney permitted auntient lawes fee point abrogated europe asia yea italie selfe whence lawes fee many thinke first tooke beginning lewes sfortia gouernour lombardie sent agent fraunce king charles eight haue obtained nephew duke milan might receiued homage deputie duchie gene whereunto king would condescend question made taking fealtie homage marque salusse court paris decreed deputie shuld admitted name king thought good marque pretended himselfe sicke yet condition soone able come doe himselfe person hath also bene oft time iudged like case contrariwise lord fee may constraine vassall yeeld fealtie homage vnto deputie commonly vsed vassall yet vnder age young yet wanteth vnderstanding borne fealtie homage vntill age except pleaseth lord fee receiue deputie king lewes xj philip commines ambassador receiued fealtie homage mother young galea duke milan duchie gene duke sonne vnder age paying fiftie thousand ducat reliefe cause treatie made betwixt lewes eleuenth maximilian archduke austria yeare 1482 56 article expresly set downe subiects part receiued homage atturneies otherwise haue bene constrained themselues person haue done bene sicke iust reasonable let bodie collegiat much concerneth honour lord patron whether homage done vnto person king vassall oeher base atturney deputie cause agreed treatie amiens made betwixt philip faire french king henrie king england yeare 1303 king england himselfe persom come fealtie homage without exception otherwise letted sicknesse without deceit case send eldest sonne doe fealtie stead another treatie made yeare 1330 betwixt philip valois king edward third also said king england person come doe fealtie homage without fraud sicknesse letted ceasing hee also come treatie peace made yeare 1259 betwixt lewes ninth french king henrie second king england expresly declared king england person yeeld fealtie liege homage vnto french king liege homage tearme force person prince pope emperour therein excepted forme homage declared treatie yeare 1331 betwixt philip valois french king edward third king england hauing hand ioyned put forme homage made king england vnto king fraunce betwixt hand french king chauncel fraunce french king shall thus say vnto king england thou shalt become liege man king fraunce duke guyenne peere fraunce countie poitou monstrueil shalt cannot agree el altogether law vse condition vassall ought made hard vnto one man one heire much harder bee enforeed doe many duty many seruices many time giue faith much liege vassall cannot giue florines vnto emperour rodolphe also genowayes say emperour enfranchised howthe genowayes afterwards hauing receiued great harme venetian gaue themselues protection vnto king charles sixt french king long vnto duke milan receiued vpon condition therefore fealtie homage vnto french king like case luca paied vnto emperour henrie fift twelue thousand florines enfranchised sienna ten thousand peter gambecourt payed twelue thousand vnto emperour charles fourth seignorie pisa true alienation exemption subiection rather simple graunts gift certaine priueleges gouerne estate vnder obeisancethat prince cannot alienat thing publike demaine successor may resume empire also power emperours neither prince whatsoeuer alienat thing publike demaine much lesse right soueraigne maiestie alwayes power successour lay hand thereon againe lawfull lord lay hold vppon fugitiue slaue emperour maximilian hauing thrust armie italie power king lewes xij hauing brought great feare vpon city italie gaue well vnderstand time florentine sent ambassador vnto yeeld vnto fealtie homage estate obtaine confirmation priueleges cost fortie thousand ducat albeit cosmus duke florence force armes made himselfe lord sienna yet tooke inuestiture therof yeelded therfore sealtie homage vnto king spaine perpetuall lieutenant empire sufficient reason show sienna enfranchised exempted empire pope iulius second pay thirtie thousand ducat maximilian emperour redeeme libertie sienna intent inuest therein 〈◊〉 duke vrbin yet neuerthelesse letted duke florence conquered force armes constrained take inuestiture thereof king spaine pay therefore sixe hundred thousand crownes afterwards king spaine would haue againe repayed vnto duke florence haue restored sienna former estate would enformed king spayne would haue giuen duke parma reunite placence parma vnto duchie milan whence bene distracted could german emperours subiects vnto estate empire alienat demaine right soueraigntie giuing right soueraigntie vnto city italie libertie vnto tributarie people seeing absolute soueraigne prince cannot much distract one clod publike land much lesse giue away proprietie king great prince say truely haue proprietie publike demaines nay much whole vse profit thatthat prince haue proprietie publike demaine onely bare vse contenting themselues bare vse rest belongeth vnto commonweale cause emperour power custome customes lawes abolished lawes customes beeing alwayes authoritie power magistrat againe put execution lawes custome almost vse custome also propoundeth neither reward punishment whereas law alwayes carrieth either one law permissiue easeth penaltie another law briefe custome hath force sufferance long pleaseth soueraigne prince may make thereof law putting thereunto owne confirmation whereby scene force lawes customes lieth power hath soueraigntie commonweale first chiefest marke soueraignty power giue lawsthat power make lawes cannot vnto subiects communicated commaund generall illatum non ex senatus authoritate non populi iussu quod quis vnquam de sua sententia facere ausus est warre made vpon gallogrekes neither authority senat commaund people man durst himselfe euer orator like spoken aduersarie manlius absent sometime done haue example declared spurius posthumius consull also himselfe armie shut vp strait rockes appennin mountaines daunger hunger perish hee could haue heard senat people would haue haue done deliuer himselfe roman armie straites himselfe made peace enemie though vpon verie hard dishonourable condition armie disarmed returned rome senat himselfe hope prince cruelly reuengeth owne iniuries pardoneth wrong done others especially directly done dishonour almightie god haue said concerning grace pardon graunted soueraigne prince vnto men condemned vttermost extended euen vnto preiudice great lord vnto whome confiscation offendours land good law custome belong receiued debate impugne pardon graunted prince decree parliament hath bene markes soueraigne maiestie except legitimating bastard fee like rest partly magistrats hauing vnderstood cause partly lawes customes vsually graunted lawes charles vij charles viij expresly commaunded clause ioyned vnto decree magistrat hath vnderstand fact punishment thereof reserued vnto law pardon vnto soueraigne prince cicero crauing pardon caesar ligarius saith haue oftentimes pleaded thee iudges neuer said defended pardon lord deceiued thought euer hee againe c child vse say vnto parent whome craue pardon iudges say crime euill forged accusor slanderer witness false subborned word plainely shewed▪ caesar hauing soueraigne power also power life death graunt pardon judge liege fealtie homage appeareth one greatest right sixt marke soueraigntie soueraigntie haue declared respect due exception right power coyne money nature lawthe seuenth marke soueraigntie none hath power make law appoint value weight stampe coyne well vnderstood greeke latine worde latine word nummus▪ seemeth well haue beene de •… iued greek word 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 nothing commonweale greater consequence next vnto law value weight stampe coyne haue spe▪ ciall treatise declared euerie well ordered commonweale none soueraigne prince hath power appoint read rome value victoriat appointed set downe done expresse law people albeit senat decree ease publike necessitie made halfe pound copper much worth pound quarter much worth pound vntill ounce valued much worth pound yet done consent tribune without nothing senat therein decreed force constantine emperour made law coyned false money punished men guiltie high treason law prince haue straitly kept taking vnto themselues confiscation false coynes excluding others haue claime thereto like punishment also punished without prince leaue coyne good money albeit many particular men realme auntient time priuilege coyne money countie touraine thethe right power coine monie inseperable marke soueraigntiec granted vnto subiects bishop meaux cahors agde ambrun county paule marche neuers blois others yet king francis first generall edict took away priuileges could indeed graunted beeing graunted law made void ioyning hereunto also endure life graunted haue showed nature priuileges howbeit marke right soueraigntie ought sort communicated vnto subiect well declared sigismundus augustus king polonia yeare 1543 hauing giuen priuilege vnto duke prusse coyne money estate countrey made decree wherein comprised king power giue away right beeing inseparable crowne selfe reason archbishop gnesne polonia archbishop canterburie england chauncelours hauing obtained right priuilege king thereof againe depriued cause city italie holden empire former emperours obtained priuilege coyning money treatie constance gaue vp vnto emperour excepting luca vnto fauor pope lucius third countrey man emperour request graunted priuilege read also principall occasion peter king arragon tooke hold driue iames king maiorque kingdome hauing coined money pretending right power doe also one occasion lewes xj tooke hold make warre vpon francis duke britaigne hee stamped coyne gold contrarie treatie made yeare 1465 roman suffered money brasse siluer coyned prouinces yet forbid coyned gold reseruing still vnto themselues howbeit iohn duke berry priuilege charles fift french king coyne money mettals hee would thing therein offend caused peeces gold bee coyned figure sheepe vpon finest purest gold euer either since coyned realme yet omitted though prince contrarie vnto law shall giue man power stampe money worth valour thereof stil dependeth soueraigne prince sort coyne haue profit thereby stampe onely prince wonderfully vaunt glorie auntient time roman commonweale whilest popular state triumuiri monetales master mint coyned money stamp marke themselues thought good name letter thereuppon iii viri ff caulis baileiffe mountaines interpreteth aere argento auro flauo ferunto truely thus trium viri auro argento king seruius first coined monie rome aere flando feriundo truely seruius king roman first stamped heauy coyne brasse figure impression oxe vpon imitation theseus king athens coyned money theplutarch theseo figure marke figure owle whereby appeareth greeke latine prince old haue bene touched vaine desire glorie wherewith prince tormented wherafter king asia affrike greedily longed first coyned first stamped image darius name dariques whereof king darius ielous herodotus writeth caused ariander gouernour aegypt bee beheaded hauing stamped money owne image cause also emperour commodus beheaded minion pecenninus also king lewes xij hauing left power right soueraignty vnto genowayes ouercome forbad neuerthelesse stampe money marke figure owne image stead forme gibbet gaue yet giue vpon money marke iustice power coyning money one right markes soueraigntie eight marke soueraigntie also power appoint measure weight although customes receiued none pettie lord pretendeth haue right whereby commeth passe infinit varietie weight andthe great varietie waights measure hurtfull commonweale measure commonweale taketh small harme cause king philip faire philip long lewes xj resolued kingdome one manner weight measure commissioner appointed purpose comparing together made euen measure weight realme brought matter good effect king lewes death bene taken away fully perfected yet soueraigntie maiestie law self commonweale cannot stand without tax tallages president hath well noted tax leuied realme since time saint lewes king must need must publike necessitie leuied taken away cannot bee done hath soueraigne power hath bene iudged decree parliament duke burgundie many time since aswell high court parliament also priuie councell diuers particular lord city corporation vnder show common good haue imposed diuers tax payment vpon people king charles ninth generall edict made parliament orleans expresly forbiddeth doe without leaue albeit common necessitie borne withall without commission exceed summe twentie fiue pound afterward edict straitly againe renewed moulins well agreeing law equitie although roman senat time warres yea censor themselues imposed certaine tax payment could hardly haue bene extorted bodie whole commonaltie yet still passed sufferance tribune people ost time also opposed themselues yea sort presented request vnto people time forward man vpon paine head bee hardie cause law passed campe senat subtill meanes campe sutrium caused published notable imposition called vicesima manumissorū say twentith part good manumised vnder colour pay armie withall thereunto right willingly agreed suffered law passe inthe romaine commonweale greatly relieued great rich paulus emilius brought rome ouerthrowe king perseus second carthaginensian warre time great want coyne common treasurie law made taxe generally imposed vppon euery man another contrarie law againe repealed returne paulus aemylius spoyles perseus king macedon filled citie euerie priuat soueraigntie one bodie giueth lawes vnto rest people whether generall particular thing themselues cleerer day true writer auntient time therein well agree lesse three kindes sortes commonweales whereunto others haue ioyned fourth composed three fift diuers rest plato hath vnto three well adioyned fourth kind wit better sort excelling rest vertue haue soueraignetie allthe diuers opinion vntill senat determined done state lacedemonian commonweale endured fiue hundred yeares vntill time cleomenes hauing slaine ephori senatours oppressed commonweale tooke vppon himselfe soueraigntie held vntill time ouercome antigonus king macedon hauing vanquished restored commonweale state howbeit twentie yeares fallen againe power nabis tyrant afterward slaine philopomenes commonweale vnited vnto state achaean whereof prouince vntill thirty yeares gallus roman proconsull taken achaean roman emperours set libertie thus word may see true historie lacedemonian commonweale part taken xenophon thucidides liuy polybius whereof yet man hath curiously written plutarch lacedemonian act publike record hath corrected thing others haue bene slightly falsly set downe reported hath giuen occasion many deceiued thinke state haue bene mingled three diuers kindes commonweales plainly gathered liuie bringeth nabis first tyrant lacedemonia thus speaking titus flaminius noster legulator lycurgus non paucorum manu rempub •… esse voluit quem vos senatum appellatis nec eminere vnum aut alterum ordinem ciuitate sed per aequationem fortunae dignitatis fore credidit vt multi essent qui propatria arma ferrent lawgiuer lycurgus saith would state commonweale bee men hand call senat neither would haue one order excell rest citie making equall men fortune dignitie thought would come passe many would beare armes countrey thus couereth tyrranny show popular state popular estate yet said truely lycurgus beginning gaue soueraigntie vnto people let v see rest also haue put example roman commonweale said haue bene mingled three kind commonweales saith polybius maister africanus great wee see saith hee regall power consul aristocratie senat democratie peoplethe romaine commonweale meare popular state composed three formes commoweals vnto whome plainely assent dionysius halycarnasseus cicero contarenus sir thomas many others opinion neither grounded vppon truth reason monarchie say soueraigne gouernment one man two consul cannot bee imagined soueraigne maiestie consul could possibly diuided betwixt two indiuisible nature thereof seemeth probable reasonable attribute vnto duke genu venice regall power could bee two roman consul could neither make law peace warre neitherno soueraigntie romaine consulls great officer neither graunt pardon neither take peny common treasure neither much whip citisen time warre without leaue people hath bene power alwaies giuen gouernours army whome also may call king greater appearance consul power one space one yeare onely constable fraunce chiefe bassa turkes bethudere aethiopia edegnare kingdome afrike haue ten time power two consul together yet subiects slaues prince consul subiects seruants vnto people purpose say consul royall authoritie seeing least tribune people might imprison drusus tribune sergeant tooke philip consull coller cast prison hee interrupted speaking vnto people might lawfully doe shall hereafter declared power consul lead army war denounced assemble senat present letter captaines ally vnto senat giue audience vnto ambassadours people senat call together great estate demaund aduise people election officer promulgation lawes yet standing spake vnto people sitting ma downe token subiection vnto people authoritie consul chiefe gouernour citie absence ioyne hereunto also consul power one yeare wherefore leaue opinion scarce worthy refuting concerning senat say haue forme power ofthe smal power romaine senate therein resemblance aristocratie aristocratie farre neuer priuie councell authoritie power vntill time persian manner adored afterwards gon king presence hee courteously spake vnto word excused done seemely themistocles follow fashion countrey wherein man grecian make great reckning libertie equalitie commaund esteeme best thing world reverence serue honour king image living god wherevnto agreeth liuie writeth barbaris pro legibus semper dominorum imperium fuerunt commaund lord haue beene alwaiesa lordly monarchie accounted tirannie whie vnto barbarian lawes neither ought lordly monarchie accounted tyrannie inconvenient soueraigne prince hauing good lawfull warre vanquished enemy make himselfe lord good person law armes governing subiects doth good housholder seruants slaues wee see thing receiued manner custome almost nation prince shall vniust warre vnlawfull meanes wickednesse haue filthyly abused name truely king holy yet pride tarquinius rauishment lucretia sonne made hatefull vnto roman crueltie scylla dictatorship made dictator odious immoderat ambition francis valori made confalonniers florence hatefull vnto florentine also euident name tyrant haue bene hateful nation oppressing people may one prince whose dominion large wide may beare himselfe king vnto naturall subiects lordly monarch towards whome hath iust warre subdued tyrant toward rest citie may tyrannise ouer rich better sort citisens yet show himselfe courteous gentle vnto poore baser sort amongst tyrant diuers sort degree lesse good prince hath notable vice wee see none cruell tyrant endued good vertue hath thing commended wherefore thing euill example thereto daungerousa soueraign prince action subiects rashly censured▪ withall rashly foolishly censure prince whose action comportment throughly know whereas ought first wisely weigh vertues vice heroicall base euill disposition manner persian condemned man death although conuicted crime whereof accused except first appeared former life whether vice exceeded vertues liuie well hauing diligently reckoned vp hannibal vertues comming afterward vnto vice saith tot ac tantas virtutes ingentia vitia aequabant many great vertues counteruailed great vice wherefore least good confused confounded bad •… vnder name tyrant comprehend also right worthy famous men let v compare worst tyrant best king comparison two extreames may bee better perceiued middest betwixt say best king meaning thethe best king common manner neither doe seeke one accomplished heroicall vertues rare paragon iustice wisedome religion man without imputation fable auntient worthy propounded magnificence truth prince looke vpon imitat endeuour bee indeed one codrus decius reported haue bene aduertised oracle victorie ouer enemy depended death without farther delay sodenly sacrificed liues moyses aboue whome philo calleth wise law giuer iust prince besought god might rather die euerlasting death wicked haue name blotted booke life people committed charge endure great grieuous punishment deserued prayer hee appeased wrath god like good king true father people name augustus great emperor reported neuer haue heard title addition vnto pleasing time valerius messala decree senat people rome called father countrey best prince nothing differeth best father xenophon woont excellently say greatest difference betwixt king tyrant king conformeththe greatest difference betwixt king tyrant himselfe vnto lawes nature tyrant pleasure treadeth vnder foot one respecteth religion iustice faith whereas regardeth neither god faith law one referreth action good commonweale safetie subiects whereas respecteth nothing owne particular profit reuenge pleasure one doth endeuour enriching subiects whereas seeketh nothing impouerishment encrease owne wealth one accounteth owne good good people reckoneth onely good euen body subiects also owne one seuerely reuengeth publique iniuries done state easily pardoneth wrong done vnto himselfe cruelly reuengeth owne pardoneth done others one easily forgiueth offence men owne misdeed seuere judge whereas sharply reuengeth euen least offence others vnto himselfe fauourable one fauoureth honour modest matron men wiues triumpheth shame dishonour one refuseth bee freely discreetly reproued hath done amisse hateth nothing graue free spoken man one enforceth himselfe maintaine keepe subiects peace vnitie whereas seeketh still set od ruinat one another confiscation land good enrich himselfe one taketh pleasure see subiects oftentimes seene heard whereas feareth presence hideth himselfe enemy one reposeth estate fealtie loue towards feare one taketh care subiects feareth nothing one chargeth subiects little neither exacteth thing publike necessitie requireth whereas drinketh subiects blood gnaweth bone also sucketh euen marrow meanes seeking weaken one aduanceth vnto highest degree honour best vertuous men whereas stil promoteth greatest theeues villaines whome may vse spunges sucke vp wealth subiects one frankly bestoweth greatest gainful office state vpon men best desert free briberie corruption may defend people iniurie oppression whereas setteth sale giue robbery vnreasonable exaction keepe people vnder afterward well fatted cut degree hath slaine soueraigne prince euen also hath attempted hath giuen councell consent thereunto yea haue conccaled much thought fact lawes haue detestation man guiltie offence crime dieth thereof therof accused albeit lawes inflict punishment vpon euill thought men onely word deed breake enormitie yet man shall much conceit thought violating person soueraigne prince although haue attempted ofttimes power kill cause haue bene killed dauid innocent prince whome got manie victory ouer enemy time fell twice himselfe dauid hand blamed valiant souldiers ouer commaunded would suffer mortal enemie power slaine assured hope haue enioyed kingdome death detested counsel saying god forbid suffer person king lord annointed violated yea moreouer hee himselfe defended king persecuting hee commaunded souldiers guard ouercome wine sleepe wakened time saul slaine souldiour thinking dauid pleasure presented saul head dauid forthwith caused souldier slain brought head saiing go thou wicked durst thou lay thine impure hand vpon lord annointed thou shalt surely die therefore afterwards without dissimulation mourned himselfe dead king worth good consideration dauid saul persecuted death yet wanted power haue reuenged himselfe become stronger king aid enemy vnto whome hee fled euen besides chosen god annointed hand samuel king people also married king daughter yet abhorred take vpon title king much attempt thing life honour saul rebell chose rather banish himselfe realme sort seeke king destruction also read holy best learned men euer amongst iewes▪ whome called essei say true executor law god held soueraigne prince whatsoeuer ought bee vnto subiects inuiolable person sacred sent vnto god wee doubt dauid king prophet led spirit god alwaies eies law god saith thou shalt speake euill thy prince detract magistrat exod 23 28 neither thing common holy scripture forbidding onely kill attempt life honour prince euen verie magistrats also although saith scripture wicked naught therfore guiltie treason god man doth detract magistracie punishment sufficient shall attempt life law god case yet precise lawes men law iulia holdeth guiltie treason shall giue councell kill magistrat whereas law god expresly forbiddeth sort speake magistrat euil wise detract wherefore aunswere vnto vaine friuolous obiections argument maintain contrarie idly abuse time learning doubteth whether bee god argument refuted seuere punishment bee chastifed also call question thing cleere bookes publikely imprinted subiects may take vp armes prince beeing tyrant take way howsoeuer howbeit 27 ambassadours fraunce renue confirme former alliance example popular city haue set downe thereby force nature popular state commonweales might better vnderstood wherefore let v conclude popular state commonweale wherein greater part people haue soueraigntie whether voice giuen byaristotle opinion concerning aristocratical popular commonweale poll tribe company parish community yet aristotle writeth vnto contrarie must saith according common opinion iudge estate popular greater part people haue soueraigntie afterward example bringeth forth xiij hundred citisens citie thousand better richer sort haue soueraigntie excluding rest ought saith deeme popular state aristocratie wherin lesser part citisens haue soueraigntie men poorer sort concludeth thus popular estate wherein poorer sort citisens haue soueraigntie aristocratie richer sort beare rule whether moe fewer one much concerneth meanes aristotle establish owne reiecteth common opinion people yea euen philosopher lawgiuers themselues common receiued opinion hath alwaies beene shall mistris matter state yet neither true probable reason depart common opinion whereas thereof ensueth thousand intollerable ineuitable absurdity might say faction decemuiri ten commissioner appointed correcting amending euill lawes customes rome taking vpon soueraigntie popular estate albeit history call oligarchie although barenes commonwealth chosen wealth wisedome onely contrarie people maintenance popular estate driuen man might say state chaunged aristocratie also say twelue thousand richer sort soueraigntie fiue hundred poorer sort excluded state aristocratie againe contrarie fiue hundred poore gentleman gouernment ouer rest richer sort one call commonweal popular state saith aristotle calling commonweales appollonia thera colophon popular state wherein auntient verie poore family soueraigntie ouer rich yea passeth saith greater part people hauing soueraigntie giueto iudge estate consider haue magistracy office soueraigntie resteth great office honour state vnto fairest tallest citisens shall popular aristocratique estate foule errour matter state considering iudge estate question know haue magistracy office onely bee haue soueraigntie power place displace magistrats officer giue lawes vnto euery man absurdity others also much greater ensue hereof thatthat state commonweale may one sort yet gouernment therof another quite contrarie aristotle hath mistaken manner forme gouernment commonweale soueraigne state thereof haue said state may pure royall monarchie yet gouernment popular namely prince giue honour office preferment therein poore aswell rich base aswell noble indifferently without respect accepting person also may state royall yet gouernment aristocraticall prince giue honour office nobilitie richer sort onelie fauorits contrarie people hauing soueraigntie giue honorable office reward preferment vnto nobilitie onely rome vntill law canuleia estate deed popular yet gouerment aristocratique nobilitie better sort haue soueraigntie yet bestow honorable charge preferment vpon poorer baser sort aswell vpon rich without fauour respect person state aristocratique yet popularly gouerned greatest part people hauing soueraigntie shall giue honorable office preferment indifferently without respect person lot bestow vpon citisens man might wel iudge estate onely popular also popularly gouerned done athens request motion aristides whereby citisens receiued office commonweale without respect wealth contrarie law solon whereby prouided bestowing honour place authoritie commaund regard also bee vnto men abilitie wealth likewise nobilitie onely richer sort haue soueraigntie state exclude rest people honorable place preferment commonweal keepe themselues alone one might say estate aristocratike also aristocratically gouerned wee may see state venice happily man say none selfe opinion one auntient much lesse moderne writer intreat matter state commonweales haue touched point true cannot denie yet distinction neuerthelesse seemeth vnto necessarie good vnderstanding state euery commonweal man cast himselfe head long infinite labyrinth errours see aristotle himselfe haue fallen mistaking popular commonweal aristocratique contrarie wise contrarie common receiued opinion yea contrarie common sence also principle euill grounded nothing firme sure possiblie thereon built errour likewise sprung opinion haue forged forme commonweale mingled three haue good reason reiected wherefore let v firmely set downe resolue three formes ofthat state commonweal may power commaund matter state people rome might saw good confirme •… repeale decree senat power commaund much lesse execute decree therof dionysius halycarnassaeus hath well noted liuie himselfe oft time vsing forme speech senatus decreuit populus iussit senat decreed people commanded wherein festus pompeius deceiued interpreting word iussit commaunded decreuit decreed belonged senat decree people commaund liuie speaking authoritie scipio africanus saith nutus eius pro decretis patrum pro populi iussis esse beck stead senator decree people commaunds least tribune people opposing himselfe senat might stay decree thereof haue noted certaine place titus liuius whereby euidently appeareth senat could nothing commaund especiall decree said consull thinke good present request vnto people making dictator pleased consull praetor citie take charge vpon would therin nothing one tribune consul saith liuie would therein doe nothing forbad praetor also obey senat senat much power commaund consull one tribune people would neuer haue vsed kind speech neither would consul haue forbidden praetor obey senat indeed senat could commaund praetor vsed like word seeme vnto good pleasure man another place saith decreuerunt patres vt marcus iunius praetor vrbanus si ei videretur decemuiros agro samniti appuloque quoad eius publicum erat metiendo deuidendoque crearet senator decreed marcus iunius praetor citie thinke good appoint ten men measuring diuiding much samnite appulian land belonged commonweale man say word si ei videretur seeme vnto good imported commaund contrarie proued saith power iurisdiction yet case saith simply praetor deputy absence gaue commission preuenting gf daunger might meane time happen men necessitie must driuen runne still vnto praetor like case also haue nothing deputed precarie iurisdiction right call nothing thereof owne wherefore whether power duumuiri consisted onely hauing power commaund iurisdiction vndoubtedly leaue sufferance whereby vnderstood duumuiri properly haue bene magistrats haue power commaund together iurisdiction may call men attache penall iudgement defend iurisdiction also put iudgements execution wheras haue power command without iurisdiction may well cause man apprehended proceed deceiued old law alteria tarpeia power giuen magistrats impose fine vnto summe threescore six shilling therefore suppose magistrats haue iudiciall power also fine magistrat imposed publike iudgement sake tribune people lawfull partie fined either pay fine without examination matter appeale vnto people trie cause fine liuie oft time bee seene done law icilia fine selfe inflicted infamie vpon partie fined publike crime sake punishment beating staues impaired man reputation cause wherefore beaten fine set vpon obeyed magistrat sending aunswering asked cause impairing credit lawfull magistrat taking distresse exact fine without appeale law tarpeia certaine stint measure fine appointed set downe vnto magistrat disobedient citisens might without trouble state kept order insolencie restrained least fine vpon man imposed one sheepe greatestthe auntient fynes romaine magistrats impose vpon offender two ox thirtie sheepe according diuersitie cattell made penaltie either lighter heauier could hardly brought looked vnto citie sheepe valued ten ass oxe hundred say many pound brasse afterward rich territorie roman hundred whereas dioxysius writeth haue bene lawfull onely consul impose fine ought seeme strange time law made neither praetor aedile rome first praetor made 386 yeares foundation citie cicero hauing thought best made lawes commonweale imitation plato conceited amongst rest made one whereby giueth vnto magistrats iurisdiction diuination thinke haue bene verie roman lawes see cicero much deceiued hereafter show magistrats haue also iurisdiction yet seemed vnto cicero good profitable yet magistrat hath iurisdiction speake properly whether haue owne right others hathpower commaund stil annexed iurisdiction auntient bishop bishop also without power commaund properly iurisdiction onely simple hearing vnderstanding matter lucullus bishop said senat bishop haue bene judge religion senat law tendeth end vnderstood question religion credit bee giuen vnto vnto men skilfull profession trade vnto iudges appointed either bare examination fact properly called recuperatores terme delegate christian religion christian bishop augustine nicephorus iustinian witnes much least iurisdiction matter examination priestes themselues howbeit iustinian graunted examination owne order calling neither would auncestors haue part commaunding power giuen vnto bishop court parliament paris hath oftentimes decree ordinance thereof witnessed might man say see consistory prison examination fine permitted vnto bishop thing else thing declare meere commaunding power yea philip faire king lewes sonne granted vnto bishop paris power apprehend arrest men offending diocesse howbeit suppose former thing belong rather vocation power commaund execution thereof belongeth vnto magistrats yet power staying apprehending graunted bishop paris decree senat forthwith againe taken although long since henrie second graunted vnto bishop power stay apprehend men heresie impietie yet neuerthelesse law shortly againe abrogated yea bishop themselues owne decree professe themselues haue power execution thing yet v permitted vnto stay apprehend offendours within boundes consistory court go farther fine contrarie vnto lawes bishop vpon men imposed parliament paris receiued euery man free appeal yea afterwards power taken also calling men call liuely summoning citation old decree yet extant whereby bishop paris grieuously fined vsed calling men beforethe authoritie bishop rome preferred authoritie princ •… bishop vnder colour ministring oathes contempt religion v drawne vnto themselues hearing almost matter alexander immolensis opinion power administring oath sufficient giue vnto vsurped declaration correcting edict lawes haue said appettaineth belongeth vnto haue soueraigntie restitution extremitie law concerneth letter justice greatly appeareth soueraigne prince haue much prince therein declare himselfe know truth thereof yet say belongeth vnto magistrat case passe beyond prohibition soueraigne prince great difference prince declareth knoweth truth forbiddeth enquire say vniust edict law neither ought obey honest speech indeed thou canst learnedst thou thou oughtest whence haddest thou doctrine wilt thou magistrat stripe imprisoment fine yea death selfe enforce priuat men obey yea euen thine vniust commaunds yet thy selfe obey commaundement thy prince thou wilt denie thine owne commaunds vniust doth prince also denie commaundeth shalt thou iudge herein thou wilt need iudge shouldst thou thinke suffer thine owne decree concerning priuat men besides man enforced thee take vpon thee thine office man forbiddeth thee giue vp law thou likest seeme thee vniust therefore desire bearing rule maketh thee thou wouldest beare rule ouer priuat men yet obey thy prince thy selfe wherefore let v vpon conclude much better obedience stoupe vnto soueraigne maiestie inferior magistrate come prouinces sit place justice may iudge ordaine commaund superiours vnto inferiours prohibit proceed generall superiour magistrats towards inferiours saith law iudicium soluitur ventante eo qui iudicare iusserat vel qui maius imperium ea iurisdictione habet iudgement stayed forbidding commaunded hath greater power iurisdiction word imperium power signifieth onely power commaund forbid euen magistrat himselfe cicero saith maius imperium à minori rogari ius non est lawfull greater power examined lesse would say magistrat commissioner equall superiour power bound answere companion one lesse himselfe maxime auntients messala lawyer declareth example thus minore imperto maius aut maiore collega rogari iure non potest quare neque consules aut praetores censoribus neque censores consulibus aut praetoribus turbant aut retinent auspicia censores inter se rursus praetores consules que inter se vitiant et obtinent greater power cannot right examined lesse fellow office fellow officer though greater selfe wherefore neither consul pretor trouble keepe southsayings censor neither censor consul pretor censor amongst themselues againe pretor consul among themselues one hinder preuaile word messala hee saith himselfe haue writ xiiij booke c tuditanus hath failed saith praetor etsi collega consulis est neque praetorem neque consulem iure rogare potest pretor although consul companion right examine neither pretor consul happely done errour write haue said praetor etsi collega praetoris est pretor although pretor companion consulis consul except salue matter saying consul pretor censor fellowes companion quia solo ijsdem auspicijs ijsdem comitijs id est maioribus creabantur caeteri magistratus minoribus auspicijs comitijs alone created chosen diuinations assembly say greater whereas magistrats chosen lesser otherwise latin neuer abused word collega sence besides pretor neuer consul companion fellow well contrarie appeal might lawfully made pretor consul read aemylius lepidus consul receiued man appealing pretor orestes contrarie decree reuersed pretor decree read also luctatius consull tooke triumph valerius pretor consull generall armie although day armie wherein victorie got showeth also power consull haue beene greater pretor consull twelue lictors pretor two citie sixe sent prouinces greekes therefore called 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 law lectoria prouided made concerning power pretor citie pretor greatest praetor vrbanus duo lictores apud se habeto isque ad supremum solis occasum ius inter ciues dicito pretor prouost citie let haue two lictors let administer justice amongst citizen vnto going downe sunne wherefore let stand good onely fellowes companion power also magistrats like equall power haue power examine one another therefore much lesse haue greater power themselues yet question may whether companion fellow office one lesserwhether companion fellow office may stay proceeding equall superiour difference right great betwixt commaundement empeachment opposition companion fellowes office haue commaunding power one ouer yet neuerthelesse may publique action one oppose themselues hinder one others proceeding fellowes office although haue power one ouer yet may well hinder one others proceeding piso pretor judge betwixt straungers citisens rome oft time troubled verres pretor citie thereto consent might take place one fellowes himselfe alone might empeach stay aduise decree resolution whole societie contrarie formall disposition law willeth act concerning communie corporation greater part stronger part two third part may giue lawe fellowes particular whether rest fellowes present absent needfull present decree stand good especially light matter prouided yet thereunto summoned called howbeit matter waight consequence needfull two third part present albeit giue consent except speciall law prouided two third part must necessitie agree one iudiciall lawes lewes xij french king ordained two part iudges fewer may higher court end ciuill cause whereas criminall cause equall voice acquite partie accused yet otherwise condemned greater part one voice exceed lesser also decree gregorte x concerning election pope must haue two third part colledge cardinal chosen pope also many election head colledges necessarie two third part colledge agree one yea sometime necessarie fellowes one selfe accord rome tribunitiall law requisite ten tribune one opinion mind least wise openly discent otherwise one tribune alone might empeach stay proceeding whole colledge agreed one vnto decree ioyned word pro collegio colledge otherwise speciall statute law contrarie greater part two third part sufficieth act concerning communitie corporation colledges also necessarie consent whereof speake bee giuen common assembly corporation colledge albeit fellowes seperately making decree colledge corporation consent giuen cō •… assembly time plac •… statute •… eof appointed apart consented vnto thing concerning common colledge yet act effect purpose neither haue giuen consent although done euen publique notary done colledge done fellowes apart neither sufficeth corporation colledge called together time place statute appointed wherefore two part fellowes gathered together fellowes consenting apart man may aske shall call fellowes together wherein many opinion auntient fellow colledge societie hath power belongeth call fellowes together colledge societie call rest together also condemne contumacie comming▪ yet haue power fine ridiculous thing contumacie cannot punished neither yet colledge certein cannot wherfore calling fellow together auntient fellow vaine except fellowes owne accord content obey therefore senat consulship caesar could assembled called together caesar greatest magistrat forbidding afore said othersome opinion hold two third part colledge may right call together rest yet shall call together two third part say howbeit two third place solemne assembly meeting stil preferred owne vertues nobilitie auncestours together cōmended prince hath made noble although account worth either vertue vertues auncestorsciuil nobilitie prince vnworthily bestowed true nobilitie learning knowledge yet consent lawyer accounted ranke order nobilitie therefore plinie writing traian said caesaris esse vt nobiles efficeret ac tueretur emperor part make noble men also defend thē nobilitie bartholus vnfitly hath called ciuil nobilitie declaring therby haue gotten certein counterfeit kind nobilitie opinion men yet indeed haue part honor true nobilitie without vertue wherefore let v graunt inioy fruit ciuill nobilitie vnto whō prince gift grant conferred▪ whether nobilitie money reward pryme youth foule filthy seruices prince bestowed vpon bestow nobility belongeth onely haue power soueraigntie also whome bartholus writeth haue principalitie especially subiect vnto commaund superiour prince haue fellowes companion gouernment cannot much make man base borne bee legitimate much lesse true haue written minion domesticall attendant prince therefore become noble albeit thereby enioy certaine priuileges exemption seruices yet therefore accounted noble except haue borne greater honorable office place commaund yet question see haue often time beene demaunded whetherwhether honorable fe •… make man noble •… ▪ chaunce casualtie hath obtained great place seruice fee thereby made noble see haue pleased many honorable power commaund knit ioined fee duke county marquess title nobilitie soueraigne prince expresly set downe charter graunts homage fealtie giuen vnto thing themselues professor thereof hereof rise beginning noble vnnoble fee custome countrie wherein fee deemed right nature land possession concerningnobilitie depend land fee right person artificer inheritance purchase possesseth dukedome nothing therefore noble possessed tributarie land seemed vnto auncestours absurd thing right land fish honour otherwise not▪ person themselues giue place vnto thing picture vnto table painted much indignitie right nobilitie beof vertue nobilitie trafique made bought sold two greatest thing namely vertue nobilitie euripides plainly witnesseth trafique made 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 wherefore seeing customes aswell customes german spanyards brittons italian fee whether please tearme priuileges base vassall whereby appeareth wealth rich neuer great neither get bring forth true nobilitie howbeit thatwealth rich neuer great bring forth true nobilitie euripides bringeth person according opinion shamefull villaine thereto rich withall shall therefore degree superiour vnto honest poorer sort men thinke say much lesse ought iudge murtherers men polluted kind villanies abound wealth therefore honourable aediles senat apart diuided people first beheld thing euerie nouelty vseth doe gaue occasion speech deeming length giuen vnto honourable order long time haue right beene giuen interpreting fiftie six yeares sodenly done senator contented haue people mingled theatre rich scorne poore man sit new proud insolencie neuer senat nation either desired ordained last reported africanus also himselfe haue repented consull hee beene author matter thus much whereby vnderstood preseruing popular libertie concord degree ought placed degree al may easily bee ioyned vnto societie communion together wherefore fact africanus blamed onely common people euen senator themselues whose fauour thought haue gotten tullie writeth haue bene blamed onely wiser sort euen himselfe also force people extorted vntill bene willingly graunted vnto senator albeit seat indifferent vnto yet neuer people would presume sit behold playes senator hundred yeares law made l roscius otho tribune people knight due place large declare finis lib tertij fovrth booke concerning commonweale chap ¶ rising encreasing flourishing estate declining ruine commonweales commonweales take beginning either familie beginning commonweal little little encreasing el arise multitude people colony drawne another citie commonweale doe young swarme bee fly abroad vnto another place slip science pluckt tree planted straunge soyle taking root bringeth forth much plentifull pleasant fruit doe tree grow vp small kernel owne accord yet one commonweales established either strength stronger themselues power others voluntarily subiected themselues together libertie vnto power pleasure others disposed soueraigne power without law else vpon certaine law condition betwixt agreed vpon commonweale hauing taken beginning well rooted grounded first assureth selfe al externall force inward disease self little little gathering strength groweth vp vntill come full perfection selfe wee may call flourishing estate thereof cannot long continuance reason thethe florishing estate commonweales endure long chaunges worldly thing mutable vncertaine greatest commonweales oftentimes fall euen weight themselues others caligula cruell emperours thing commonly happeneth popular estate wherein new tyrant force fraud hauing oppressed libertie people neuer assured themselues estate without great strong garrison see alexander medices nephew pope clement seuenth sonne law emperour charles fift whose force power hee obtained soueraigntie florence draue also greatest power courage state haue compassed himselfe great strong garrison alwaies haue gone armed sort seemed almost impossible find meanes come neere yet haue bene slaine conspiracie laurence medices onely neere kinsman familiar domesticall friend also▪ said laurence promised prostitute vnto owne sister might better deliuer man disarmed euen kissing embrasing sister thought haue rauished murtherer slaine▪ couertly done souldiours guard whome kept vertuous raigneth long since missed much haue bene •… laine conspiracie puccinus neither bee safe without strong garrison long citisens subiects shall either remember hope reward valour libertie cause motion without cause blameth iulius maturnus placed sunne first house mercurie tenth cannot saith except sun mercurie fourth part circle three signes distant hauing regard globe may placed encline collected celestiall theames many famous city differeth altogether theame rome taruntius set downe placeth libra east doth also manlius absurd thing none absurd ouerthrow city measure destruction estate commonweale whereas haue declared city oftentimes may ouerthrowne laid euen flat ground yet state commonweal therof remaine haue shewed citie carthage oftentimes contrarie estate commonweale may perish wall building yet standing whole wherefore rest vpon opinion much lesse vpon cardan saith seeme subtilly others handle hidden obscure matter raise admiration himselfe men vnskilfull thing maintaineth beginning encreasings greatest city empire haue come starre last taile vrsa maior saith haue bene verticall vnto great citie rome foundation thereof thence euen helpe working starre translateth roman empire constantinople afterwards fraunce thence germanie although set downe brainsicke man yet docardan error detected opinion reiected men ignorant celestiall motion wonderfully admire therfore v refuted perceiuing last starre vrsa maior daily vnto manie people verticall though perpendicular vnto onely subiect vnto circle starre describeth cardican saith verticall time sun toucheth meridian circle state supposeth haue beene time romulus founder citie laied foundation thereof could nature viz last starre vrsa maior howre say noonetide together sun touch verticall circle starre third part circle foure signes twentie degree distant verticall ought haue beene signe degree signe wherein sunne cardan doctrine true yet knew starre haue beene verticall vnto many great city affricanus writeth time called bizance againe afterwards also taken pausanias king lacedemonia median warre yet afterwards also besieged alcibiades generall athenian long time three yeares together againe besieged seuerus emperour sacked razed also downe ground carrying away rest citisens captiuitie gaue ground whereon stood vnto perinthians yeare lord two hundred yet long againe reedified constantine great wonderfully enriched thither translated seat empire yet againe fire sword cruelly wasted armie galienus emperour citisens therein either slaine else caried away captiuitie yet ceased still seat greeke empire vntill frenchman fleming vnder conduct baldwin earle flaunders seized thereon held together empire vntill fiftie yeares palaeologi againe driuen hauing recouered citie raigned vntill mahomet great turke woon change empire ruines citie gauricus neuer touched neither cardan himselfe much suspect otherwise suppose would neuer haue written thing absurd disagreeing themselues great maruell cardans starre hath power graunt empire world italie greece fraunce germanie verticall yet hath power vpon realmes norway sweden onely verticall sunne meridian moneth august also euen sufficient let office perpetuall rather annuall end euerie man hauing therein part interest might also haue occasion liue peace yet farther reason also perpetuitie office promotion onely vnitie concord subiects true reward vertue taken away due punishment lawes appointed offendors thereby also impeached rather quite abolished whereof wise law giuer ought haue greater regard reward vertue due▪ wise accomplished man looketh reward vertuous action vertue selfe man cannot say vice neither vitious cause lawes god man euen first vnto last haue commaunded nothing punishment wicked punishment man vppon alwaies high mounted impossible come nigh shall accuse shall imprison shall condemne shall companion fellowes power cut owne armes rip owne entrals beleeue neuer euill aduised great one bee also partaker foule robbery villanies extortion shall punish others rather blush shame touched compassion like vnto themselues hainousnesse offence enduced take punishment hardie accuse yea much considerationno lawe good draweth discommoditie also profit thereof seeing law good saith c •… censor draweth incommodities mine opinion law may alwayes accounted good profitable good may ensuethat good law changed one discommoditie ensuing thereof thereof manifest greater harme feared thereof wherein many often time offend thinke impossible haue discommodities quite taken lawes commonweale yet neuerthelesse still standing safetiedangerous change cheife magistrats commonweale falling daungers thought straight way blame lawes often time chaunge truth haue accused chaunged selues good prince euill aduised often time harme cancell good law one incommoditie haue seene therein▪ whereof vse example lewes xj comming crowne displaced father auntient seruitours remoued also prince nie kinsman gouernment state therefore wonderfull consent conspired enemy brought strait almost strucke crowne head force wrested roiall scepter hand sturres againe quieted thing well pacified set order fearing lest sonne fall like daunger charged neuer chaunge aduanced yet contented made law whereby decreed office perpetuall preferred thereunto againe displaced otherwise resignation death forfaiture edict declaring former published xx september yeare 1482 decreed officer hauing forfeited office cause soeuer enforced yeeld vp office except adiudged party condemned edict hee commaunded stand force onely whilest himselfe yet liued also raigne sonne charles albeit could bind hand successour yet neuerthelesse decree law hath euer since bene inuiolably kept although auntient clause long shall please v remaine still letter office word declare perpetuall power giuen vnto magistrats officer sufferance onely except law custome otherwise prouided yet still remaineth idle clause thereby may vnderstood power authoritie haue auntient time bene giuen king pleasure haue magistrats bene holden sufferance onely albeit raigne philip faire string againe touched giuing office perpetuitie yet matter still rested vndecided philip valois reuoked commission ordained time forward royall office bee perpetuall well declareth haue beene mutable pleasure king albeit officer forfeited amongst praise giue vnto king robert one greatest neuer displaced officer foule infamous fact forfeited office whereby gathered king robert auncestours haue vsed lawes customes yet haply may seeme vnto office still giuen clause prince pleasure magistrats would better discharge charge hope haue meane continue still place proceeding still better better bearing themselues vprightly feare otherwise displaced whereunto agree well ordered lordly monarchy daunger greater open gap vnder prince euery side beset flatterer compassed clawbackes euerie man seeth prince beset must either make filthy gaine traffique office else take place power commaund good men almost alwaies haue courtier life polluted manner vice hatred detestation besides thatthat office royal monarchie rather bestowed order law prince pleasure onely bestowing office pleasure sauoureth somewhat tyranny lordlike gouernment rather royall monarchy much possible lawes prince pleasure onely bee gouerned many lordly monarchie subiects naturall slaues adore feare soueraigne prince god come downe heauen accounting commaunds lawes nature selfe whereas royall monarchy subiects child needfull rule gouerne thing law much possible may otherwise king shall without cause exclude one office preferment bee excluded hold himselfe iniured rest discontented prince ought rather beloued feared subiects bee ought take away occasion discontentment men might haue better meanes none leaue may disposition lawes customes man hauing iust cause complaine prince learned budeus opinion best haue magistrats office still changeable without hauing regard vnto law made lewes xi hath holden auntient time president counsellor parliament paris annuall solemne oath still take 12 day nouember letter patent still haue king opening parliament show sufficiently estate perpetuall still pleasure prince bee reuoked bee holden sufferance reason drew many opiniō erection parliament paris turned ouer record court chamber account haue found parliament ambulatorie moueable power commission philip long ordayned ordinarie court ordinarie power circuite iurisdiction erection whereof expressed still haue therein one two president first earle burgundie king nie kinsman like sort president imperiall chamber alway one prince empire long time also president court paris still martiall man gowne man euen yet present great praetor court paris call chiefe president still honored qualitie title martiall man knight latin call mile souldiour although neuer drew sword title judge court haue three score hundred fiftie whereby plaine court paris founded haue ordinarie perpetuall power neither haue need prince annuall rescript letter patent disciding determining controuersies howbeit king henry second comming parliament publishing certaine edict lawes court could hardly find passage hauing put mouth certaine flatterer said openly parliament power pleased sending letter patent euery yeare giue opening vnto speech astonished many certaine letter patent sent end annuall oath president councelours take matter formalitie custome necessarie time parliament holden commission afterwards erected forme ordinarie court auntient solemnity necessarie annuall magistrats take annuall oath whereas perpetuall magistrats take without needlesse reiteration continuall roman magistrats euery yeare tooke oath power annuall wheras senator tooke dignitie perpetuall whole time liues might said forme commission decree court conceiued vnder name seale king namely letter missiue court although bee conceiued name court yet neuerthelesse sealed little royall seale flowredeluce howbeit magistrats seneschal bailiefes prouosts gouernours country hauing power ordinarie commaund commission direct vnder owne name owne seales yet retained auntient forme euer since parliament king priuie councell councell ordinarie power nothing selfe commission alwaies graunted name king hauing onely power commaund councell haue shewed forme hath bene euer since followed erection parliament euen vnto court aide giue commission vnder king name •… hath moued say parliament haue nothing extraordinarie power way commission onely howbeit sufficiently appeareth v said haue ordinarie perpetuall power still hold king beeing dead power holden vpon sufferance would haue together death king take end power commission else doe court ordinarie magistrats thereof king dead neither chaunge attire vse mourning garment signes sorrow yea first confirmation new king alwaies graunted vnto court parliament hath beene alwaies vsed since time lewes eleuenth sort power onely ordinarie perpetuall also onely whole body themselues euen euery one member officer minister said court parliamentthe giuing office prince pleasure discommended yet manner prince discommended vnto officer magistrate giue power sufferance cause pleasure againe take king england haue vsed doe albeit auntient moderne commonweales especially popular aristocratique straitly bound vnto lawes monarchy haue magistrate officer part annuall none againe displaced without iust cause yet people sometimes reuoked former choice made placed others knew fit charge vndergoe establishing dictator others captaines gouernors reuoking sometimes say euen ordinarie magistrate octacilius consul request fabius maximus remoued charge man sufficient mannaging great daungerous warre state hand neither remouing magistrat regard onely thing trespassed deserued remoued euen vnto insufficiencie also whither knowne vnknowne receiued estate befallen afterwards deeming also weaknesse age madnesse like disease let hinder men reasonable action sufficient also displace office namely lucius torquatus chosen third time consul excused himselfe people infirmitie eye saying reason put gouernment commonweale hand could see men eye many blind deafe dumbe hauing themselues light nature neither wisedome experience much gouerne themselues yet content guide sayles tackle desire also lay hand euen vpon verie helme also commonweale haue said concerning meane ought kept chaunge continuation magistrats officer hath onely place royall monarchy euen popular aristocratique estate also officesthat euery commonweale ought estate magistrats perpepetuall almost part ought euery yeare two yeares two yeares still mutable among swissers diuers commonweal yet neuerthelesse preseruation must still estate commonweale perpetuall namely whose experience wisdome alwayes necessarie stay rest councellors estate senat rome athens lacedemonia still perpetuall senator still liues held charge place hooke hinge whereupon great burden rest must themselues strong vnmoueable euen senat areopagi commonweales also strong sure hinge whereupon well mutable officer whole waight estate commonweale rested reposed themselues contrarie whereof done monarchy wherein greater part almost estate ought perpetuall except chiefe principall doe kindome spayne well know keepe mediocritie meane proper vnto royall estate cause venetian haue aristocratique estate make officer euery yeare chaungeable two moneths two moneths yet neuerthelesse haue duke procurator marke chauncelour foure secretary estate perpetuall florentine ordayned estate also lewes xij deliuered cruell tyrannie countie valentinus borgia taking order duke time forward perpetuall entent commonweal perpetuall motion chaunge estate office might yet haue thing firme stable whereupon rest stay selfe good order short time turbulent florentine abolished fell againe greater tumuls ciuill warres euer whereas perpetuall senate least senator continued charge six moneths six moneths stil chaunged rechaunged kept certaine meane betwixt two extremity generall chaunge still continuing office estate beene much assured neither commonweale beene still tossed turmoyled many great surge sedition tempest ciuill warres thing thus v declared let v see also whether wise well ordered commonweale good magistrate vnitie one accord among themselues chap v ¶ whether vnitie concord magistrats amongst themselues bee good wholesome commonweale question viz whether good magistrats officer commonweale accord el discord variance among themselues may perhaps seeme altogether needlesse vaine euer doubted alwaies expedient yea necessarie magistrats euerie commonweale reason show magistrats ought vn tie concord among themselues one mind end together might one consent heart embrace seeke publike good wise men haue alwaies thought well ordered commonweale ought resemble man bodie wherein member vnited conioyned maruellous bond euerie one office dutie yet neuerthelesse need one still aideth another one releeueth another together strengthen themselues maintaine health beautie welfare whole bodie happen enter hatred one another one hand cut right foot supplant left finger scrape eye euerie member draw vnto selfe nourishment next vnto must need fall bodie end must become maimed lame impotent action therof euen like manner may man deeme estate commonweale honour welfare whereof dependeth mutuall loue good subiects among themselues also toward soueraigne prince sweet vnitie agreement hoped magistrats principall subiects▪ ought example bind together rest variance discord among themselues euen contrarie subiects shall become partaker faction magistrats first nourishing secret grudge afterward open enmitie vntill length breake open ciuill warre maintenance vpholding euerie one chiefe faction destruction commonweale case stay made thereof thing fall altogether euill yet must still publike action ambitious discord magistrats hindred commonweale sore troubled whereunto shall happen doth vnto maid whome plutarch saith suters enter ielousie passion desiring euerie one haue himselfe stead louing embracing cruelly rent peeces amongst good successe may man expect armie victorie bee hoped ouer enemie captaines commaunders discord among themselues iustice looked judge diuided faction yea hath bene oftentimes seene haue beene contrarie opinion aduise vnto others vpon verie iealousie hatred among themselues play hazard life good honour subiects agesilaus king lacedemonians albeit hee one famous euer impaire credit authoritie lysander whome hated reuersed iudgements gaue sentence quite contrarie much iniquitie cause himselfe said despight enemie onely make matter short certaine dissentions ciuill warres capitall plague commonweales take foot root encrease nourishment nothing hatred enmitie magistrats among themselues whereof followeth vnitie concord among thmselues vnto subiects onely profitable euen necessarie also may seeme right profitable argument reason one side subtilly reason matter deeme contrariecontrary reason show good commonweale magistrats discord variance among themselues health welfare commonweale best preserued kept discord magistrats say force nature vertue cannot contrarie vnto vertue neither good men although bee neuer great oddes yet enemy among themselues prouoked iniuries wicked aduersaries still wel encrease flourish neither valour worthy men euident manifest without bitternesse contend among themselues prickt forward honest ambition enflamed heat men like vnto themselues fire emulation competitor incited take hand great matter still ouercome enemy well taxilas king indian ambassadours freely without resistance offered kingdome vnto alexander great bearing downe kingdomes east wanted wealth withall refused receiue wealth also hand hee much alexander glad match said vnto must thus contend combat together shall neuer said shall take point honour accounted magnificall courteous royall selfe gaue vnto another great kingdome infinit masse treasure like manner tullus hostilius king roman said vnto metius suffetius dictator albanian ciuill discord thou obiectest vnto v wee deem profitable citie striue together whether v shall better earnestly fight good commonweale contention emulation thus good profitable amongst valiant good citisens wholesome commonweales much ought thought necessarie base abiect men stirring vp vertuethe fruit •… oes deterring vice great profit men vse reap enemy none greater liue seeme exceed vice ouercome vertues discord contention honourable profitable citie commonweale wherein prince magistrats good men striue vertue onely much shall contention profitable good striue euill case magistrats euill discord contention amongst onely profitable euen necessarie also least otherwise beeing vnitie concord among themselues possession gouernment might freely without feare make hauocke spoile publike priuat affaire case cannot fall better either subiects whole commonweale mutuall hatred accusation shall openly detect lay open vnto world owne filthinesse foule extortion robbery sheepe neuer assured wolues deuoure one another happened saith philip commines england whilest great lord slew condemned one another poore people meane remained safe inuasion wise councell cincinnatus seeing consull appius openly withstand people hinder doubling number tribune wisely commonweale stood flourished tribune oftentimes discord varience among themselues vnitie concord would haue moment fallen long well stood vntil pub clodius wicked man foure hundred yeares
