aristocratique estate one accord discord accord alwaies like better commaund others sort preserue estate together commonweale quite ouerthrow owne power whereunto discord would bring giuen sayles vnto tempest sort liuie said caluinus campanian improbum hominem sed non ad extremum perditum qui mallet incolumi quàm euersa patria dominari wicked man saith altogether desperate rather rule ouer countrie yet standing vpright ouer ouerthrowne albeit mar tullius said threeheaded alliance caesar crassus pompee thing greatly feared yet saw crassus moderator roman legion slaine chaldea iulia caesar daughter pompee wife vntimely philip 2 death taken away cried vtinam cn pompei amicitiam cum caesare nunquàm coisses aut nunquàm diremisses would god pompee said thou haddest either neuer made friendship caesar hauing made haddest neuer broken friendship much diminished popular power enmitie altogether ruinated one wise able endure equall superiour vntill ciuill warre state quite length ouerthrowne caesar become master caesar writeth auncestours auntient gaules haue thought dissention prince great gouernours haue beene profitable vnto estate hardly perswaded therein report euen caesar himselfe dissention prince estate fraunce part gouerned aristocraties wrought owne destruction praying aide german roman long prey one end vnto roman alone onely conqueror neither true mutuall slaughter nobilitie england haue beene commodious profitable vnto comminaltie inferiour sort philip comines writeth yea time embassadour england vnderstood inhabitant feare nothing faction nobilitie ciuill discord better appeasing repressing whereof haue often time vsed assemble high court parliament whereunto state assembled thus haue declared sort magistrate ought behaue selues towards prince also ought beare selues one towards also towards priuate men whether ought vnitie among selues remaineth v briefly show also prince ought behaue selfe towards subiects whither expedient selfe iudge selfe conuersant among chap vi ¶ whether conuenient expedient maiestie soueraigne prince iudge subiects selfe much conuersant may seeme vnto question reasoned hath doubt needfull v farther enter considering auntient wise polytitians accord king neuer thing established administration justice saith herodotus speaking medes cicero likewise romanskings first established iudge subiects also read first king greece aeacus minos radamanthus title honorable title iudges great equity administred iustice poet reported haue obtayned iupiter euerlasting power office iudging ghost hel albeit homer calleth prince pastor feeder people yet title iudges hath long time continued person prince athens soueraigne gouernment ten yeares onely prince medes greek latin euen general also soueraignes amongst hebrewes title title iudges time demaunded samuel wearied age king ioyned thereunto might iudge king people showeth sufficiently principall charge doe iustice themselues person principall reason might moue prince themselues iudge thereasons show prince themselues person ought administer iustice vnto subiects subiects mutuall obligation betwixt prince subiects subiect oweth vnto lord duety aide obedience prince also oweth vnto subiects iustice guard protection subiects bound obey prince prince administer vnto iustice neither sufficient haue done man magistrate prince command seeing subiects commaunded yeeld faith obedience vnto prince cannot deputy onely themselues person obligation betwixt prince subiect reciprocall howbeit lesse inconuenient vassall giue faith homage vnto lord deputie lord iustice officer obeisance subiect case cannot called doubt whereas subiect hath warrant magistrat officer shall suffer himselfe bribe corrupted prince therefore still aunswerable god vnto cannot say hath therewith charged conscience iudges owne thereby discharged besides much notably concerneth commonweales hold soueraignty themselues doe iustice wit vnion amitie prince subiects cannot better nourished maintained communion one lost brought nought prince nothing magistrats officer seemeth vnto subiects prince disdaine contemne thing vnto grieuous prince selfe doe wrong much heauy contumelie disgrace isthe great good ensueth whē prince person themselues iustice vnto subiects hardly borne simple wrong iniurie whereas contrarie subiects see prince present selfe person vnto iustice go away halfe contented albeit haue desired least wise say king hath seene request hath heard difference hath taken paine iudge cause subiects king seene heard vnderstood almost incredible much rauished contentment pleasure prince neuer little vertuous haue commendable qualitie besides greater meane giue authoritie vnto magistrats officer cause iustice selfe feared reuerenced see king selfe sitting regall throne subiects iustice moreouer magistrats often time doe wrong iniurie vnto subiects standing vpon nice clause word sillables law dare passe bound subiect thereunto case make conscience iudge according strictnesse law must yet first send reason vnto prince attend aunswere exposition edict lawes made according vnto opinion aduise officer often time see suters purse bothom sort many sutes liue longer party suters selues yea time euer suspended whereas prince selfe person shall vouchsafe iudge matter liuing law aboue ciuill lawes accompanied counsell shall doe good speedie iustice hauing respect vnto verie ground equitie matter without farther standing vpon title formality meanes also many opposition appeales ciuill request remouing cause infinite decree one vpon make sutes immortall cease iustice without stay let take course appeal made prince ioyning hereunto also commonweale relieued great charge wage alloweth vnto iudges particular fee aboue measure heauie besides bribe present must giuen often time passe ordinarie fee sort subiects steed hauing good speedie iustice prince oweth constrained paie precious thing world howbeit oftentimes happeneth marchant well paid yet marchandise deliuered right little nothing worth yet another verie considerable point also party contending sometimes great honourable would neuer answere many judge discredit vnworthinesse iniquitie like qualitie whereby oftentimes commeth passe end suit difference combat dynt sword whereas prince presence might euen twinkling eye set agreed greater profit thereby come vnto commonweale prince vse exercise iudgement haue force right iustice throughly engrafted mind greater better thing could bee wished almightie god either prince subiects hee might curiously seriously learne daily administer iustice knowledge artes science selfe thing royall proper vnto king knowledge armes martiall affaire well fitting prince enemy whereas iustice necessarie time place whether peace warre rest altogether vpon reason argument also vse examplesexamples great prince themselues person administred iustice vnto subiects herein wise noble prince vvhat man amongst men wisedome compared salomon yet read onely prayer made vnto god obtaine wisedome wherewith rightly iudge people prayer acceptable vnto god seemed therefore plentifully great world wonder haue powred vpon treasure wisedome knowledge men might vnderstand god onely haue inspired wisdome also office right iudgement euen god himselfe giuen vnto king also experience great affaire politike wisedome like vnto great augustus yet neuerthelesse wee read without ceasing still busied administration iustice insomuch euen sicke caused himselfe bee carried horselitter doe iustice howbeit ordinarie vacant time roman emperours administration iustice commended aboue prince worlda notable example great emperour adrian poore old woman iustice euen farre poore old woman great emperour adrian refused aunswere preferring vnto request excusing leasure raigne longer said discharge thee thy charge thou bearest whereunto emperor hauing answere presently staid iustice great prince whose empire bounded bound course sunne troubled great affaire acknowledged bond doe subiect iustice ought doe hold scantling great empire ought euerie one enforce himselfe owne person studie power imploy himselfe iustice considering plinie yonger saith noble philosophie entreat publike affaire doe iustice putting practise philosopher haue taught knowledge right administration iustice bring many great profit vnto prince much greater shal necessarie prince vnderstand affaire estate shall themselues handle thing onely proper vnto soueraigntie rest ciuill affaire prince may well commit vnto magistrats right soueraigntie deciding hee wise put together soueraigntie self surely verie blind deafe dumbe neuer men eies see men eares heare another man tongue oftentimes straunge tongue also speake talke thing proper vnto themselues wee haue shewed also example straunge nation onely euen example auncestours also idle slothfulnesse king committed mannaging affair vnto domesticall seruants haue thereby brought themselues posteritie vnto destruction argument reason thus v alleaged make faire show vnto sufficiently vnderstand experience know secret soueraigntiereasons show meet prince themselues person administer iustice vnto subiects hidden knowledge maintaining maiestie vnto looking neerer matter sufficient resolue question maintaine prince ought person himselfe administer iustice yea vnto mee seemeth onely necessarie profitable vnto subiects prince himselfe bee vnto minister iustice true bee onely profitable euen necessarie also prince themselues scylax faigned vnto himselfe king indian say much better subiects god aboue men earle flaunders neither yet philip long french king cause robert earle flaunders attainted treason yea decree sentence giuen name peer name king albeit himselfe present bee seene sentence giuen robert also awe whereunto also well agree young king might doe amongst lady gentlewoman take pleasure knowledge news enough amongst prince great lord man shall obiect say prince oftentimes yea enforced doe take part thinketh himselfe wronged vpon obstinatwhen soueraigne prince vse force appealing controuersies quarrel betwixt great subiects mind reason persuasion iudgement arbitrement suffer himselfe ouerruled persuaded case say necessitie hath law yet prince hee may come point extremitie vse force ought proue meanes possibly may composing matter controuersie making great subiects friend may force strong hand ouerrule could otherwise doe cannot shall froward presumptuous hearken vnto reason friend persuasion haue many take part stand fast great obstinat wilfulnesse yet might man say occasion quarrell may secret proofe thereof made neither iudgement giuen yet hee hath receiued iniurie demaundeth thereof amends case prince find themselues oftentimes much troubled iniurie offence vnto man secretly offered done denieth trueth cannot therein tried onely bare surmise coniectures case amongst common vulgar sort bee done easie thing say man ought without manifest witness condemned souldiours asthe beginning combat stand vpon nobilitie deeme honour stained reputation greatly impaired except haue satisfaction vpon oath affirmeth himselfe haue bene man secretly wronged men say whome wee euen spoke cause theodoricus king gothes though fauouring arrians would yet enforce conscience subiects haue tormented religion least vnder pretence impietie hee haue seemed haue taken exercise religion otherwise shall cometo forbid men priuat exercise religion make oftentime •… become atheist passe destitute exercise religion withall distasted religion others shall become altogether atheist wee daily see haue lost feare god tread also vnder foot lawes magistrats inure themselues kind impiety villanies impossible man lawes redressed howbeit lettteth v follow councell command lawes feare god iudgements greatest tyranny nothing miserable anatheisme worse greatest superstition anatchie neither prince magistrat none obeieth neither yet commaundeth men liue list libertie loosenesse life without feare punishment greatest superstition much thing detestable atheisme truely mine opinion offend much thinke punishment bee appointed make many god would haue none infinitie god admitted almightie euerliuing god thereby taken away superstition great soeuer doth yet hold men feare awe law magistrats also mutuall duty office one towards another whereas meere atheisme doth vtterly root men mind feare euill wherfore two inconueniences propounded▪ superstition say atheisme must still decline greater yet may publikely vse true religion still consisteth worshipping one almightie euerlasting god least contemning religion publikely receiued seeme allure stirre subiects vnto impietie sedition better come vnto publike seruice mind still rest honour reuerence one almightie euer liuing god whereas men maruell came passe time theodosius many sect better agree commonweale two onely considering diuersitie sect religion could stand without ciuill warres least hundred diuers sort according account tertullian epiphanius whereof cause multitude varietie different opinion still held one counterpoise another matter sedition tumult nothing dangerous haue subiects diuided two opinion faction onely whether matter estate religion lawes customes matter whatsoeuer subiects diuided one thing nature contrary vnto another thing moe thing one contrarie vnto one thing imagined moe two sect sort must need meane betwixt two contrarie extreames may set agreed otherwise themselues would neuer fall agreement therfore solon law prouided ciuill sedition trouble euery man ofwhether solon law parttaking▪ euery man necessitie bound take either one •… part time sedition good profitable vnto commonweal necessitie take either one part bee lawfull man stand neu •… er vnto many seemed thing vnreasonable considering greatest prayse commendation good subiect bee quiet ciuill man desirous best liue peace besides mean conscience honest man forced take either defend depriue life selues liue briefe law god forbiddeth knoweth truth follow common opinion way whereunto solon law seemeth repugne forcing man take either one part although naught howbeit man might say vnto contrarie solon law profitable necessarie also vnto popular aristocratike estate wherein soueraigne standing neu •… er may determine decide difference shall bee discord variance men well know people north haue alwaies bene great drinker witnesse greeke prouerbe drinke like scythian tacitus hath forgotten speaking manner german diem noctemque inquit continuare potando nulli probrū ita vt deceiued saying german drinke eat lesse reason coldnesse barrennesse countrey contrariwise seeing thirst nothing else appetite cold moisture hunger appetite drought heat people north haue interiour made himselfe king murther nephues defeated slaine earle richmond bin banished france whence brought small ayde king lewis 11 giuenthe roman alwayes fortifie camp happens fortified country retreat cause roman neuer camp cast vp trench armie 25 foot broad commonlie palissadoes neither euer giue battaile left garrison within camp make good retreat enemy stronger hath relieued great loss paulus aemilius wisely discourse vnto armie gaue battaile vnto king macedon saying maiores nostri castra munita portum ad omnes casus exercitus ducebant esse vnde ad pugnam exirent quo iactati pugnae receptum haberent qui castris exutus erat etiamsi pugnando acie vicisset pro victo habebatur elder held camp well fortified safe retreat euents went forth fight retired beaten lost camp although titus liuius saith discipline first constrained incursion bordering neighbour iealous greatnesse hauing afterwards brought people italie vnder subiection treated alliance finding people giuen armes could liue idly peace without ciuill warres found expedient good commonweale seeke new enemy making warre sometimes reuenge wrongsthe roman sought occasion warre done vnto confederats sometimes defending enemy graunting triumphes honourahle estate great reward valiant captaines wisely ordained senat healthfull remedie ciuill warres bebius tribune people obiect vnto father warre sowne vpon warre people might neuer quiet therefore distinction betwixt militarie charge office iustice one selfe citisen might valiant captaine wise senator good iudge great orator said cato censor well skilled tillage appeareth bookes yet ashamed leaue armes goe plough leaue plough plead sometimes iudge sacrifice play oratour people senat caesar high priest tully opinion excellent orator best captaine age many onely italie also greece excelled art warre policie read iulius pollux athenian bound go warre foureteene yeares continued vntill threescore therefore aristides pericles phocion leosthenes demetrius phalerian alcibiades themistocles infinit grecian like vnto theplut phocione auntient roman excell art warre policie wisest polititians seperat art warre vocation commonweale creet euerie man allowed carrie armes certaine speciall person inplut licurg old time fraunce whereas horseman charge druides exempt aegypt none calasires men warre licurgus herodot allow therefore plato diuided citisens three order keeper men armes labourer imitating aegyptians made three seuerall kindes estate little little athenian made distinction armes policie iusticein phocione roman truely short course life doe excell politike art seemes augustus first take senator proconsul gouernours prouinces power weare armes succession time called office without armes dignity wee dion lib 53 read cassiodorus quamuis inquit omnia dignitatum officia manu secludantur armata forma comitiue written gouernour prouince ciuilibus vestibus induti videantur qui districtionem publicam docentur operari tua tamen dignitas à terroribus eruatur quae gladio bellico rebus etiam pacatis accingitur arma ista iuris sunt non furoris although saith hee office dignitie bee excluded armed hand seeme bee attired ciuill garment taught labour difficulty commonweale yet dignitie seemes pluckt terrours guirt warlike sword euen quietest time armes iustice furie consequently nation degree haue separated souldiours schollers men justice beeing difficult thing excell one art impossible worthily exercise many victory moreouer thing almost impossible traine subiects commonweale vp armes maintaine obedience law magistrats haply cause made king francis first cast seuen legion foot erected within realme yeare 1534 euery legion containing six thousand foot although sonne henry renew twentie yeares yet forced alter opinion seeing commonweale troubled mutiny growne many place meanes legion yet opinion straungers haue iudicially examined goodly ordinance made end neuer thing better instituted art ofthe entertainment legion necessarie state warre necessarie realme part world enuironed warlike mightie nation make common practise spoyle like countrey conquest yea entertained foure legion foot besides troopes horse defence realme placed garrison vpon frontier prouided wisely safetie commonweale fraunce twentieth part roman empire guard whereof augustus caesar said fortie legion suffice fiue thousand men legion foure legion foot troopes horse paied time peace according ordinance king francis first would haue cost three hundred fiftie thousand pound starling yet halfe much legion augustus time whole pay men armes fraunce yeare 1560 came 235300 pound starling well old band men armes augustus entertained fortie legion horse aud foot besides citieaugustus kept fortie legion continually pay guard two nauies defence sea keeping empire safe forren ciuill warres twelue hundred thousand pound starling yeare excellent description order prince propound vnto themselues imitat orosius dion tranquillus writer haue described monument yet lawfull roman souldiours notwithstanding small entertainment rob spoyle see day meanes maintaine martiall discipline defend right citisens ally repell enemie else prest warre shall forced abandon neighbour also countrey else extremitie must vse vntrained souldiours become captaines euer souldioursthe inconueniences haue trained band else forced necessitie must beg buy forren succour deere rate doe thinke forren succour bee reiected many suppose great empire angmented▪ without succour confederats neither long resist violence enemie allow succour come ally vnited together offensiue defensiue league canton swissers least defensiue league bee house fraunce meanes onely strengthned butit good haue mightie friend ally equall league also take enemie succour might draw occasion men make warre either vnlesse hee meane professed enemie vnto desire confederats tied mutuall bond altogether equall auoid reproach quarrel inconueniences grow inequalitie league treaty vnequall one bound pay diet assembly ally although raise one companie souldiours notwithstanding bee tied pay continuall pension besides entertainment time warre succour horse foot need without pension pay treaty king fraunce make canton swissers least prince draw succour also necessarie offensiue defensiue league equall conquest common hath alwaies among canton haue made warre common whatsoeuer conquered one priuate wherein antient italian circumuented roman treaty roman hauing made offensiue defensiue league neighbor italian alwayes one romaine legion two ally readie paied generall armie alwaies romaine yet theirpolibius liuie roman circumuented ally italy treaty ally pension entertainement roman part conquest made common dignity office except townes latin absolute meanes treaty kept faith giuen senat ratified treatie polluted honour roman blemished fame worthy exploit would haue state enter league haue commerce pirats theeues ought bee partaker law nation haue said although tacferin chiefe armie theeues affrike sent ambassadours rome end appoint land place inhabit else would proclaime perpetuall warre roman yet emperour tiberius taking indignitie would much heare ambassadours saying open senat auntient roman would neuer heare treat sort spartacus slaue profession fencer captaine theeues although gathered together threescore thousand slaues defeated roman three battailes bene vanquished crassus escaped hanged whereby appeares dishonourableit dishonourable prince deale theeues prince state treat theeues hauing plighted faith vnto dignitie breake rare example emperour augustus made proclamation whosoeuer could bring vnto crocotus captaine theeues spaine haue 25000 crownes whereof aduertised went presented himselfe augustus demaunded reward emperour caused giuen vnto withall pardoned toa notable deed emperour augustus giue example others must keepe faith without respect party merit great difference whether faith giuen theefe friend enemie subiect subiect ought maintaine honour estate life soueraigne prince proue treacherous disloyall vnto hee hath giuen protectiō come capitulat prince doth infringe oath hath great cause complain theefe theese subiect legion bulgarian theeues come france dwell king dagobert gaue faith finding daungerous suddenly breake troupe loose desperat men soone vpon certaine day watchword giuen slaine great difference whether soueraigne prince doth capitulat friend enemy subiects haue rebelled maiestie comprehended treatie many haue made question prince breaking faith rebel seeking reuenge whether enemie thereby wronged assurance giuen truce bee thereby broken oftentimes falles doth afflict prince titus liuius saith philip king macedon vnares philippū maxime angebat quod cum leges romani victo imponerentur seuiendi ius macedonas qui bello ab se defecerant ademptū erat one thing tormented philip hauing law prescribed roman might tyrannize ouer macedonian fallen duringa procope tartaria sent hundred ambassadours threatning waste countrey fire sword sent backe procopes sonne taken prisoner vauoide incensed threat put death except one whome sent home maimed member bee yongest three roman ambassadours hauing threatned afterwards cause ruine estate fact king mofcouie barbarous seeing italian ambassadour put hat bidden caused bee nailed fast vnto head cruell barbarous deed yet error ambassador hold ranke dignitie prince maister bee contempt prince whome sent sometimes ambassadours relying vpon greatnesse master forget themselues meaner prince especially men bred vp popular estate accustomed speake libertie thinke may doe monarch accustomed heare free speech much lesse truth spoken vnto cause philip young king macedonie seeing roman ambassadour question boldly hee could forbeare braue reproach popilius roman legat vsed antiochus king asia greater presumption making circle rod king person willing giue aunswere went circle liuie saith obstupefactus est rex tam violento imperio king amazed violent commaund yet roman commanded hauing tried power marius elder vsed like libertie towards mithridates king pontus amasia although neither ambassadour publike charge yet said vnto king must obey commaundement people rome stronger mithridates find true spoken roman freer speech nation sometimes great libertie without iniurie offends prince cause marc anthonie caused ambassador sent augustus whipt talked freely queene cleopatra prince wisest hauing receiued affront ambassadours demaund reparation maisters charles earle charolois said vnto ambassadours lewis eleuenth chauncellour braued king would shortly repent fell yere imbarqued king daungerous warre hazard estate therefore king francis first doubting heare something herauld sent emperour charles fift might bee impeach vnto maiestie caused gibe •… set vp court gate heard hee approached letting vnderstand would hang opened mouth hauing giuen emperour lie knew well herauld could bring aunswere without touch honour dignitie bee attempt warre associats small iniurie scot old time picts taking away dogges hauing liued together almost six hundred yeares great peace amitie good prince must trie meanes dissemble many thing come armes agree bartol saith peace violated one hath vndertaken hee shall bee wronged yet thing stolne away whome hath made peace nothing sooner moue antient roman make warre thing taken away iniuries done aurelius emperour said well putasne non aliter vim inferri quam si homines vulnerentur vi est etiam cum quod per iudicem debuit per te ipse arripis doest thou thinke violence offered vnlesse men wounded violence thou takest thine owne authoritie thou shouldest recouer law make breach faith craftie interpretation law bartol proues truce lawfull french man passe england vpon condition truce found within limit shall lawfull kill end truce depart england storme driuen backe england truce expired case saith may lawfully kill opinion may ransome law kill doth nothing truce tempest cast vpon enemy countrey would seeme vniustand iniurious repaire happens accidentally losse life finis libri quinti sixt booke concerning commonvveale chap prince prodigalitie exhausted theft great benefit redounded generall many ina forfeiture double forbidden law •… pecun de vsur particular one may obiect although augustus lend publicke money interest yet hee imposed penaltie double paid prefixed day greater vsurie therfore forbidden law opinion penaltie disallowed law stipulate thing fraudulently aboue lawfull interest hath taken publicke money restores appointed day commits theft therefore penaltie theft vsurie prince therefore wisely old time prouided necessitie commonweale profite priuate men contrarie vsed day prince stead giuing vpon recouer principall foureteene hunded long creditor shall liue colledge saint george gene take money men fiue hundred deliuers againe highest interest prince marchants whereby enriched haue redeemed thereof chap iii coines meanes preuent altered falsified looking well best ground strongest support commonweale opinion hee must exactly vnderstand point wisely settle estate reforme abuse nothing doth trouble afflict poore people falsifie coines alter course thereof rich poore euerie one particular generall receiue infinit losse preiudice cannot precisely euery point bee describeddaungerous state alter coine breed many inconueniences coine may corrupted altered without great preiudice commonweale money must rule price thing mutable vncertaine man make true estate hath contract bargaines shall vncertaine charge tax wage pension rent interest vacation shall doubtfull fine also amercement limited lawes customes shall changeable vncertaine conclude estate treasure many affaire publike priuate shall suspence whereof edict made gratidianus tribune rome good argument contrarie opinion fellow tribune set certaine price kind coyne called victoriatus vpon penaltie whereby purchased great glorie himselfe posteritie erect statue euery streete offred frankinsence waxe vnto tully saith neminem vnquam multitudint ob id vnum fuisse cariorem neuer man cause deerer people prince may make false money may kill rob neither alter weight coyne preiudice subiects much lesse stranger treate traffick people subiect law nation vnlesse lose name maiesti •… king tearmed counterfetter money dante poet called philip le bel first among prince corrupt coyne mingle copper siluer cause great trouble among subiects pernitious president forraine prince whereof repented himselfe late restoring coyne inioyning sonne lewis hutin abate goodnes coynes cause peter 4 king arragon confiscate estate king maiorque minorque pretended vassall abated coyne yet thethe prince cannot alter coyne king arragon themselues erre point pope innocent 3 forbid vassal vse whereupon king arragon comming crowne doth sweare change waight price money hath allowed sufficient make protestation vnlesse value waight money ordred ought end neither prince subiect may falsifie would alwayes hauing meanes punishment soeuer inflicted ground counterfet coyners washer clipper boylers money growes mixture made mettals one mettall pure simple cannot supposed another differing nature colour waight substance sound preuent inconueniences must ordaine euery commonweale coynes one mettall without mixture publish edict emperour tacitus defended vpon losse life andcovnes simple without mixture good mingle gold siluer siluer copper copper tinne lead may except law mixture copper tinne make sounding mettall whereof bel ordinance cast much vsed old time necessarie mixe twentieth part lead pure tinne make malliable seeing may cast put worke without mixture hurt bountie tinne neuer drawne lead law must hold coynes plate work gold siluer falsehood corruption ordinarie coynes triall easie oftentimes workemanship deere substance selfe wherein archimides much deceiued seeking find goldsmith stolne great crowne king hieron deface fashion vse touchstone tooke two lump mass one gold another siluer putting either vessell full water effusion water iudged proportion gold siluer filling itarchimides error triall mettals againe water put crowne cast forth lesse water masse siluer gold whereby coniectured goldsmith stolne fift part iudgement vncertaine supposed mixture allaie pure siluer goldsmith make gold firme giue better luster make commonly copper also lesse charge much lighter siluer make gold looke paler consequence copper hath greater bodie siluer masse equall waight differs much thirteene eleuen allaie mixture copper siluer impossible make true iudgement vnlesse could distinguish much either although knowne yet shall erre insensibly measuring drop water difference masse proportion mettals refiner goldsmith world cunning precisely iudge touchstone much siluer copper mixt gold allaie one pure mettall although goldsmith iewellers haue falsly complained cannot worke gold vnder two twentie carrats without losse fine gold aboue 23 carrats three quarter according decree king francis first published yeare 1511 yet notwithstanding good order make worke twentie yea oftentimes nineteene carrats twentie foure mark fiue mark copper siluer time made base money vse counterfe •… therefore necessarie obserue proportion mixture gold wrought coynes vpon like penalty end vse gold plate moueables may pure impossible refiner say refine gold 24 carat must little mettall siluer twelue denier must allaie euen purest refining according lawes 23 carrats three quarter hath fourth part carrat allaie siluer eleuen denier two graines three quarter royal spaine else eleuen denier eighteene graines siluer paris others best hath fortie sixt part copper mixt best spanish siluer thirtie sixt part copper without great charge besides difficultie length time may worke gold plate coyne 23 carrats siluer eleuen denier twelue graines pure without allaie proportion gold siluer shall equall allaie shall alike one say 24 pound siluer eleuen denier twelue graines 24 pound gold 23 carrats pound mettall gold gold likewise siluer siluer copper mettall siluer called realme king siluer 24 part copper meanes coynes gold siluer shall stronger durable whereby get much working fier sodring keepe wasting brittlenes end iust proportion gold siluer obserued al europe neighbour nation twelue one thereabouts may bee also kept weight money needfull coine money gold siluer weight sixteen two thirtie threescore foure peeces marke without alteration either raising abating auoid one side difficultie stamping side brittlenesse fine gold siluer coine lighter one denier whereas side also make come weighing aboue halfe ounce easily counterfeited reason thicknesse thereof see portuguese gold dollers siluer weigh aboue ounce also coine three markes halfe emperour heliogabulus caused made coined stampe constantinople weighing marke gold whereof emperour tiberius presented fistie king childeric meanes neither chaungers marchants goldsmith shall euer able deceiue common people ignorant bountie weight shall alwayes forced giue twelue peeces siluer one gold euery one peeces siluer shall weigh much peece gold marke see single royal spaine weigh much french crowne according weight set downe yeare 1540 two denier sixteene graines twelue single iust value french crowne may coynes gold siluer equall weight one weight mettals haue one stampe caracture may likenesse proportion mettalls might effected hope meanes falsifie money would taken away end simpler sort may abused chaunge said peeces well gold siluer take single double oftentimes royal spayne new coyne king henry second needfull stampes diuers alike spaine yet touching siluer end shall hold certaine title soulz pettie denier liure specified edict king henry second made yeare 1551 reason payment rent amercement lord right according customes ordinance soulz shall three denier weight king siluer said sixtie three marke foure shall worth liure hath gone heretofore iustest price giuen euery peece may diuided three euery one shall weigh denier shall goe foure small denier penny shall called common denier end soulz may alwayes worth twelue denier complaint lord rent right beeing vsually paid blanch copper money may cease conuerted vnto soulzes time saint lewis▪ sixtie foure marke king siluer growing annuity purchased money rent must paid according value soulz held time rent purchased foure denier hundred yeares since third part auntient soulz needfull put vse drachma groat siluer vsed throughout therof bene made guilding thing nero great pallace guilt gallery one thousand pace long vespasian imploieda wonderfull masse guild capitoll seuen million two hundred thousand crownes guild capitoll agrippa couered temple pantheon copper guilt keepe rusting oftentimes siluer guilt although selfe neuer take rust doubtlesse may well allow holy ornament gold law commaunds haue vessel gold bed bookes yea bridle guilt argues madnesse frantike men prince doth punish seuerely price gold must necessitie rise whereof nation vehemently complaine vnto prince estate held blois moreouer siluer hauing hold little imployed siluer withall besides mynes north yeeld great store siluer gold yet alteration price made processe time insensible let valuation coines made two mettals shall equall state banishing away base money moreouer generall traffique dispersed ouer face whole earth euer cannot allow great alteration gold siluer common consent nation impossible hold price thing retaining base money altogether diuers vnequall euen price thing doth fall value money decreaseth law saith doth rise raising price mony must rise fall prince hold law mynting equall commonweal yet owne aloy soulz differs twentie graines fine siluer marke worth one denier tournois euery peece soleure gayning therefore twelue penny vpon marke great gaine fleming like conuerting testons france royalls flanders euery prince hath prouided well lawes neither gold siluer transported vnto stranger vpon grieuous punishment possible haue well executed much transported sea land although none transported yet subiects alwayes haue good mean melt alter falsifie gold siluer coyne diuersitie standard growes either license graunted goldsmith done lawes purse vp want fine siluer worke well abatement allowed enamell solder vse mocking lawes made vpon price marke gold siluer setting price please vpon work alwaies sold higher rate goldsmith lawes allow siluer fortie fiue soulz gold twelue thirteene liures vpon marke gold siluer bought dearer goldsmith marchant mint master cannot exceed king lawes neither buying stuffes coyning soone gold siluer coyned money better waight goodnes neighbor prince presently molt refiner goldsmith put plate haue coyned stranger standard wherein changer serue instrument vnder colour furnishing people money trafficke goldsmith marchant stranger certaine hath found true within 25 yeares pettie soulz decried hath coyned realme aboue two million fiue hundred thousand pound starling besides peeces three sixe blanks25 million liures found refiner goldsmith found profit haue great store gold siluer plate make vse it▪ hauing bought deere goldsmith loth sell great losse euen king charles 9 lost much hauing exchanged plate coyne whereas standard money coyned equall goldsmith could lose nothing plate fashion continues yet prouerbe siluer plate nothing lost fashion therefore preuent inconueniences standard coyned money work gold siluer must one three twentie carat without alaie mixture gold eleuen denier eleuen graines siluer found meanes reforme abuse letting farme reuenues mint confiscation amercement grow forfeiture let yeare 1564 fiue thousand pound starling yeare yet abolished moulins yeare 1566 mint farmed offred coyne greatest quantitie mark gold siluer meanes branch cut rootes abuse remained still fraud neuer cease root abuse confusion three mettals gold siluer copper ceasing neither shall subiect stranger able commit fraud shall bee soone discouered euen copper brasse money allowed realme none coyned billon mixture forbidden stranger base moneybillon shall also banished realme long prince commonweale shall coyne base money hope stranger subiects euer cease counterfet priuat receiue strange coynes also another benefit generall particular growes haue said defence mixture mettals whereby shall auoide hereafter losse siluer accounted nothing gold 14 carat vpward lost charge refining done strong water must haue sixe shilling mark besides haue said abuse officer mint shall cease regard abatement cut whichesc •… arcetes •… blages officer payed wage abolishing whereof henry 2 king france ordained payed receiuers place decree although holie good yet afterwards disanulled king charles 9 chamber accompts paris gaue king vnderstand hee lost yearely aboue thousand pound starling whereas hee reape profit mint officer paied manner nothing true meanes preuent suppresse officer mint one towne coyne sort money cause payed receiuer place lord right remaining notwithstanding auntients know nothing deducted money right brassage verie necessarie rather taxe laied vpon subiect coyning money thereby take away lord right duty old time normandie day polonia preuent notable losse subiects suffer meanes also diuersitie price marke breedes million abuse shall cease forraine coynes shall receiued melt without reckning thing lord right notwithstanding letter permission obtained neighbour prince deliuer forth money realme rate owne territory taking away occasion falsifying altering changing standard receiued coynes gold siluer shall needfull haue money coyned one citie whereas iudges mint shall remaine suppresse others monarchie commonweale haue large limit necessitie must haue place refiner shall worke▪ prohibition vpon paine death refine place come great abuse giue notice vnto ordinarie iudges preuention punish abuse shall committed well knowne abuse haue realme coyning money therefore necessarie imitate roman subiects italie temple iuno coyne three sort money pure simple gold siluer copper three maisters mint caused resined stampt publickly view world end man abused price coynes also place appointed take essay triall money request marius gratidianus reade also realme law made charlemaigne forbidden coine money pallace although empire stretched ouer germanie italie greatest part spaine since king philip faire charles sonne king iohn established many mint realme many master prouost officer euery mint abuse haue also multiplied one may obiect persian greek roman coyne money pure gold siluer copper highest value could yet falsifie reade demosthenes oration timocrates answere impossible purge commonweale cleane people thousand shall find ten value gold siluer knowne euery man haue declared prince ill aduised alter bountie money gaine thereby marc anthonie coined siluer base sooner reiected besides blame shall receiue men hazard rebellion subiects great time philip faire imbased money whatsoeuer reason certaine neuer fewer coyners counterfet money roman time money either gold siluer high standard therefore liuius drusus tribune blamed presented request vnto people haue eight part copper mingled siluer money mintmen say coine money ten denier twelue graines fine shewes euen day would admit confusion mixture gold siluer siluer highest rate also gold may see medalles gold 23 carat three quarter find marked emperour vespasian want 32 part carat 24 carat purest finest gold seene sufficeth reason haue alledged gold 23 carat siluer eleuen denier twelue graines pure let excuse themselues cannot command fire therefore demaund fourth eight part alaie cause many abuse yet may say expedient coine dobles denier baser siluer auoide heauines copper money say allowed coyne base money small soeuer proue preiudiciall practised liards soulzes although coyne nothing dobles denier yet alwaies open gap coyners deceiue common people money made hath knowledge neither doth care haue small value without inquiring bountie thereof haue letter iames pinatel written king henry 2 word sir thought good aduertise within sixe moneths haue coyned one mint soulzes base foure shilling waight vpon euery marke foure soulz goodnes mettall •… shall please maiestie shew worke acquaint losse subiects receiue grow greater preuent rigour time coyned peeces sixe blank three penny king commandement foure denier siluer two denier copper foure denier foureteene graines waight best mixture base money france like sort soone molten seene euery man knowes losse king subiect receiued two shilling fiue penny vpon marke came aboue fiue twentie hundred yet pinatel hauing gotten vnder hand commission general mint yeare 1552 caused dobles denier coined villeneufue auignon villefranche rouergue valued twelue soulz marke verified meanes stollen little lesse fortie thousand pound starling purchased pardon fiue thousand pound gaue vnto ladie fauorite king defer wicked man punishment quite free conclude therefore must meanes allow mixture smallest coynes purge commonweale counterfet money meanes also domage shall cease poore receiue decrying money deminution price thereof haue made baser neither shall haue credit prince suggest vnto profit may receiue mint certaine officer mint gaue councell treasor vnderstand also write vnto king charles 9 might make great proffit mint ease people truth computation found euery marke pure gold wrought would yeeld vnto king sixteene shilling starling whereas receiued two shilling sixe penny foure denier marke siluer wrought king get foure shilling whereas gained sixteene denier wrought testons aduised coine money king siluer twelue soulz tournois currant thirtie peeces marke waight sixe denier nine grain halfe quarter rate gold coines 24 carat one carat alaie thirtie peeces marke waight siluer six liures tournois would also haue coine small base money three denier goodnes 320 marke three denier currant kind billon base money vnder ten deniersbillon fine rating marke foureteene 28 sh starling liures tournois aduice reiected deserued ridiculous thing thinke king draw great profit mint yet ease people true plato saith man gaines another looseth losse ineuitable necessitie fell vpon subiect seeing stranger felt necessarie great prince mediate ambassador prince end generall consent forbid coining base money setting value gold siluer hath formerlie said vsing marke eight gros drachma 570 graines ounce common therefore great difficultie catholike king queene england haue alreadie banished base money coines gold spaine except pistolets money portugall highest value coines siluer eleuen denier three graines highest good haue money cast forme medall auntient greek latin hebrew persian aegiptians charge much lesse facilitie greater roundnesse perfect preuent clipper subiect bow breake marke would continue euer troubled hammering neither need cutter cisers helpe waight fall stampt moreouer shall make one day yeare also take away meanes false coyners mingle mettals easily presse stamp whereas peece stretcheth breadth couers thicknes whereas mould would make medalls mettall equall bignes waight breadth forme whereas counterfetter would mixe copper gold allowance 23 carat volume copper equall waight twise big eight part gold twise eight part lighter gold equall masse would make medall much greater discouer falsehood certaine masse gold equall masse copper doth waigh 1550 ferlins copper shall waigh 729 ferlins seauenteene eight grosse waight haue learned francis de foix great archimedes age first discouered true proportion metalls waight quantitie hold opinion siluer hath greater masse gold equall waight gold heauier siluer equall masse foure fiue part 1551 comparison 998 nine fiue copper siluer eleuen thirteene precisely 729 998 approch neerer waight substance rest except lead heauier siluer differs fifteene foureteene precisely 998 929 make vse counterfet fly mettalls tinne much lesse vse tinne poison mettalls cannot cast siluer lighter much nine thirteene precisely 600 929 much lesse disguised gold heauier tinne equall masse lesse volume equall waight much betwixt eighteene seauen •… ustly betwixt 1551 600 twise two seauen part heauier •… ron counterfet make vse melting mixt neither gold siluer brasing plate vpon iron hard discouer plinie calles feoruminatio brazing soldring counterfetters time vse seigneur villemor commissarie warres shew auntient medall iron couered siluer yet waight bignes doth easily discouer falsehood looke narrowly siluer heauier iron equall masse lesse quantitie equall waight much foure three precisely 998 634 gold impossible ferrumination soldring thing auaile coyners seeing gold lesse bodie iron equall waight heauie equall masse much sixe nine 1556 634 feared quicksiluer falsifie two mettals although approcheth neere gold waight three foure 1558 1551 haue great knowledge fixe euaporates smoke thus much touching forme coynes profit shall come casting old time vntill mine gold siluer worne spent two mettals worne lost hidden dispersed forced make money thin could marke hammer hath since occasion many abuse euen first man hauing little gold siluer stampt hammer afterwards hauing greater store erred saying bene twelue hundred yeares standing well verified auntient register seigneurie cebastian cian duke venice yeare 1175 meere monarchy yet hath bene aristocraticall estat knowledge hath long continued haue bene part chaunged cruell tyranny bloodie popular estate haue shewed elsewhere make apparant produce new example state gene hauing peace venetian meanes protection fraunce soone adornes fregoses diuided state time aristocraticall two faction whence ensued many murthers chiefe men people fell armes freed themselues subiection tooke gouernment state gentleman succession time made law whereby none might bee duke gene vnlesse anno 1506 estate gene change thereof hee plebeian since haue published another law prohibiting noble haue aboue third part officer soone sedition expelled gentleman chusing eight tribune reiected protection fraunce chose dyer silke duke whome king lewes twelft caused bee hanged▪ hee taken citie andrew doria reuolted hee power dispose state pleasure hee made choyce six house within citie others name marke rich diuided eight twentie tribe called alberghi making gentleman giuing gouernment state debarred rest common people onely exception haue libertie euerie yeare make ten plebeian gentleman receiue number nobilitie notwithstanding well executed foure twentie thousand citisens aboue twelue hundred thereabouts part state number decreed euery yeare themselues seat hath bene vacant two yeres foure moneths together chanced death clement 5 yea sometime 10 yeres election duke sauoy surnamed foelix read also oftentimes two three pope many emperor haue bene chosen empire haue stood vacant yeare two together yea whole eighteene yeares william countie holland emperour slaine albeit prince elector made offer empire vnto king spayne alphonsus tenth yet would accept thereof manifest daunger put himselfe taking vpon sueh estate exposed vnto pleasure subiects vnto enuie prince violence murtherers time vacancie wicked neuerthelesse frame kind loose libertie sort remedie polonians haue king election double penalty offence committed choyce king haue learned zamoschy chauncellour polonia ambassadour fraunce wee read also election sultan aegypt turkes subdued vnto empire vnited poore subiects best townes city whole kingdome sacked rifled mammalukes vntill one consent rest chosen sultan remedie matter shall say meane time mightno lesse dangerous vacancy kingdome make choyce soueraigne gouernor king himselfe gouernour established therein deceiued lesse hard matter make choyce lieutenant gouernour king admit might bee made without contradiction consent estate whome belongeth name gouernour yet suretie warrant faith let hauing power hand inuade estate disarme willing thereunto wee see gostauus father iohn king sweden behaued himselfe gouernour made himselfe king without expecting election lest regall power strong garrison confirmed vnto posteritie leaue gouernment vnto senat polonia auntient time rome lesse daungerous libel fine rebellion ciuill war especially impatient vnworthy reproach shall seeke bee thereof reuenged hardly without ciuill tumult bee done shall chance beare least extraordinarie fauor one subiects greatest consent court published concerneth euery priuat man right interest consisteth matter fact matter law paulus lawyer wisely aunswered one reason hath euen root ouerthrowne long discourse interpretors diuers vnlike themselues concerning euery priuat man right interest iustinian emperour thought himselfe haue beene able haue comprehended vnderthat toucheth euery priuat man right farre concerneth possible set downe law better left vnto discretion judge one law therefore toucheth euery priuat man right interest farre concerneth lawes wisely left vnto discretion judge certainly positiue law defined set downe great ocean sea small chanell enclosed shut vp yet inequalitie much greater law venice forbiddeth take interest either commodity money aboue six hundred although thing tollerable called latines vsura ciuilis ciuill interest yet law long agoe made againe growne vse either publikely priuatly kept euery respect containing arithmeticall equalitie regardeth vnlike condition qualitie person howbeit particular contract conuentions exchaunge ofarithmetical proportion iustice alwayes obserued euen particular contract conuentions wherein yet best liked thing arithmeticall proportion equalitie best liked yet euen therein alwayes obserued kept countrey men labourer certaine naturall reason well deeming ought oftentimes take lesse hier poore rich howbeit take great paine one surgeon taketh rich man fiue hundred crownes cut stone haply taketh poore porter fiue yet effect taketh ten time poore man rich rich man worth fiftie thousand crownes payeth hundred part good whereas poore man worth fiftie crownes paieth fiue tenth part substance whereas exactly keepe geometricall arithmeticall proportion alone patient die stone surgion lacke worke starue whereas keeping harmonicall mediocritie goeth well poore man cured rich surgion gaining wealth health proportion euen judge themselues haue vsed esteeme paine therefore demaund honourable fee see haue alwayes bene lawfull doe therein exceed measure remember haue happened vnto certaine prouost paris whose name harmonicall proportion vsed iudges euen taking fee easily passe ouer adiudging lawful possession litigious benefice hauing owne fee set downe thirtie crownes whereas duetie three appeale therefore partie grieued made vnto higher court thither sent ranconet president court hardly charged wrong done aunswered good fat benefice giuen sentence forasmuch many thing poore men without fee right reason richer came make amends therefore paying deeper fee whereunto president pleasantly▪ said serue taylor tooke twice much making veluet gowne making one cloth law milan appointeth judge may fee take hundred part value suit hee exceed two hundred crownes would seeme vnto ranconet vniust euery corrupt judge without proportion extorting men saw good suit may slight matter often crown therein oftentimes paine taken •… udge suit ten thousand crownes marchant still gaining rich looseth poore wherefore making lawes deciding cause wholearithmetical proportion necessarie obserued whole gouernment commonweale gouernment commonweale must still much possible obserue keepe made great excellent worke read holy scripture •… en 1 motion mouing celestiall sphere wee see god hath made one motion equall swift motion superiour sphere another vnequall motion planet contrarie vnto former third motion trepidation containeth bindeth together one enter particular nature worldly creature also find perpetuall harmonicall bond vniteth extreames indissoluble meanes taking yet part one otherthe harmonical bond wherewith world part thereof indissolubly bound vnited together coherence neither agreeable vnto arithmeticall geometricall euen proper vnto harmonicall proportion onely wherein sweetnesse consent consisteth tune aptly mixt together harsh discord tune cannot fitly mingled together see earth stone ioyned together clay chaulke meane betwixt betwixt stone mettals marcasites calamites diuers kind minerall stone grow stone plant also ioyned together diuers kind corall stonie plant yet hauing life growing vppon root betwixt plant liuing creature zoophyte plantbeasts haue feeling motion yet take life root whereby grow againe betwixt creature liue land onely liue water onely call amphibia creature liuing land water doth beuer otter tortoise like betwixt fish foul certaine kind flying fish betwixt men beast bee seene ape munkies except shall plato agree placed woman middle betwixt man beast betwixt beast angel god hath placed man part mortall part immortall binding also elementarie world heauens celestiall world aethereall region discord sometimes said giueth grace vnto sweetest harmonie▪ god also hath world mingled bad good placed vertues middest vice bringing forth also certaine monster nature suffering eclipse defect celestiall light also surd reason geometricall demonstration end might arise greater good meanes power beautie god workes might better knowne might otherwise haue beene hid folded vp thicke obscure darkenesse therefore god hauing hardened pharaoes heart wise hebrewes expound enemie god nature saith thus vnto excitaui ego te vt demonstrarem te ipso potentiae meae vim ac decus vt toto terrarum gesta mea omnium vna commemoratione praedicarentur haue stirred thee vp saith might thee declare force glorie power act might one report men bee praised throughout whole world thing truely belong vnto true report thing done aegypt lieth hidden therein diuine meaning concerning great pharao worker father mischiefe whome sacred scripture declare name leuiathan yet diuines agree others greatest enemie god man bee still becke word power god kept restrained force power mischiefes euils wrought much fret maruell without power good neither bee neither yet perceiued shut vp within bound elementarie world aboue nothing holy cleane filth wickednesse sort little staine euils shall much profit hurt whereof augustine speaking saith well qui deum immortalem vllum mali dedecus perpessurum negat nisi maius bonum consequi certo sciret denieth immortall god would euer suffer euill wickednesse bee done hee certainly knoweth greater good ensue thereof wherefore treble base voyces made sweet melodious harmonie also vice vertues different quality element contrarie motion celestiall sphere sympathy antipathy thing indissoluble meanes bound together composed harmonie whole world part thereof also well ordered commonweale composed good bad rich poore wisemen fool strong weake allied meane betwixt wonderfull disagreeing concord ioyne highest lowest yet good still stronger bad hee wise workeman others gouernour world hath eternall law decreed himselfe infinit force power ruleth ouer angel also
